I met her five years ago when she sold me a  teenager, Srey Mom, for $203 and then blithely wrote me a receipt confirming that the girl was now my property. At another brothel nearby, I purchased another imprisoned teenager for $150.'b'Astonished that in the 21st century I had bought two human beings, I took them back to their villages and worked with a local aid group to help them start small businesses. I\xe2\x80\x99ve remained close to them over the years, but the results were mixed.'b'The second girl did wonderfully, learning hairdressing and marrying a terrific man.  But Srey Mom, it turned out, was addicted to methamphetamine and fled back to the brothel world to feed her craving.'b'I just returned again to Ms. Khorn\xe2\x80\x99s brothel to interview her, and found something remarkable. It had gone broke and closed, like many of the brothels in Poipet. One lesson is that the business model is more vulnerable than it looks. There are ways we can make enslaving girls more risky and less profitable, so that traffickers give up in disgust.'b'For years, Ms. Khorn had been grumbling to me about the brothel \xe2\x80\x94 the low margins, the seven-day schedule, difficult customers, grasping policemen and scorn from the community. There was also a personal toll, for her husband had sex with the girls, infuriating her, and the couple eventually divorced bitterly.  Ms. Khorn was also troubled that her youngest daughter, now 13, was growing up surrounded by drunken, leering men.'b'Then in the last year, the brothel business became even more challenging amid rising pressure from aid groups, journalists and the United States State Department\xe2\x80\x99s trafficking office. The office  issued reports shaming Cambodian leaders and threatened sanctions if they did nothing.'b'Many of the brothels are owned by the police, which complicates matters, but eventually authorities in Cambodia were pressured enough that they ordered a partial crackdown.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell me to close down exactly,\xe2\x80\x9d said another Poipet brothel owner whom I\xe2\x80\x99ve also interviewed periodically. \xe2\x80\x9cBut they said I should keep the front door closed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'About half the brothels in Poipet seem to have gone out of business in the last couple of years. After Ms. Khorn\xe2\x80\x99s brothel closed, her daughter-in-law took four of the prostitutes to staff a new  brothel, but it\xe2\x80\x99s doing poorly and she is thinking of starting a rice shop instead. \xe2\x80\x9cA store would be more profitable,\xe2\x80\x9d grumbled the daughter-in-law, Sav Channa.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe police come almost every day, asking for $5,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cAny time a policeman gets drunk, he comes and asks for money. ... Sometimes I just close up and pretend that this isn\xe2\x80\x99t a brothel. I say that we\xe2\x80\x99re all sisters.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ms. Channa, who does not seem to be imprisoning anyone against her will, readily acknowledged that some other brothels in Poipet torture girls, enslave them and occasionally beat them to death. She complained that their cruelty gives them a competitive advantage.'b'But brutality has its own drawbacks as a business model, particularly during a crackdown, pimps say. Brothels that imprison and torture girls have to pay for 24-hour guards, and they lose business because they can\xe2\x80\x99t allow customers to take girls out to hotel rooms. Moreover, the Cambodian government has begun prosecuting the most abusive traffickers.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne brothel owner here was actually arrested,\xe2\x80\x9d complained another owner in Poipet, indignantly. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter that, I was so scared, I closed the brothel for a while.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To be sure, a new brothel district has opened up on the edge of Poipet \xe2\x80\x94 in the guise of \xe2\x80\x9ckaraoke lounges\xe2\x80\x9d employing teenage girls. One of the Mama-sans there offered that while she didn\xe2\x80\x99t have a young virgin girl in stock, she could get me one.'b'Virgin sales are the profit center for many brothels in Asia (partly because they stitch girls up and resell them as virgins several times over), and thus these sales are their economic vulnerability as well. If we want to undermine sex trafficking, the best way is to pressure governments like Cambodia\xe2\x80\x99s to organize sting operations and arrest both buyers and sellers of virgin girls. Cambodia has shown it is willing to take at least some action, and that is one that would strike at the heart of the business model.'b'Sexual slavery is like any other business: raise the operating costs, create a risk of jail, and the human traffickers will quite sensibly shift to some other trade. If the Obama administration treats 21st-century slavery as a top priority, we can push many of the traffickers to quit in disgust and switch to stealing motorcycles instead.'b'London'b'SUCCESSION \xe2\x80\x94 the handover of power from one leader to another \xe2\x80\x94 is the moment of truth for a political system. The American presidential election, for all its magnificent hucksterism, was once again a confirmation of the messy but noble dynamism of democracy \xe2\x80\x94 America does its handover of power with dignity (barring a few dubious presidential pardons).'b'Yet in the 21st century there are three Great Powers, and two \xe2\x80\x94 Russia and China \xe2\x80\x94 boast authoritarian systems ruled by tiny cabals that decide the succession of political power through mysterious, invisible and almost magical rites. The succession in China is shamelessly undemocratic and secretive \xe2\x80\x94 but firm and orderly. Moscow is different, if only because the absence of working mechanisms  for succession are a real threat to the international order.'b'Late last month, just days before President Bush hosted the surviving former presidents and President-elect Barack Obama in the White House, Russia\xe2\x80\x99s rubber-stamp Parliament was passing a law, backed by President Dmitri Medvedev, that would allow the next Russian president to serve two six-year terms, up from two four-year terms. The law\xe2\x80\x99s implications are as obscure as all developments in Russia. But it seems a maneuver to allow Vladimir Putin \xe2\x80\x94 Russia\xe2\x80\x99s previous president, current prime minister and still paramount leader \xe2\x80\x94 to return to an ever-stronger presidency.'b'Having reached the old term limit last year, Mr. Putin chose and installed a trusted prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9, Mr. Medvedev, as successor. Now many expect the president to return the favor by resigning and permitting Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s return to office. In contortion worthy of medieval Byzantium, Mr. Putin, having handed over power but actually not handed it over at all, may imminently be officially restored to it.'b'Vladimir Putin personifies the successes and flaws of today\xe2\x80\x99s Russia. However superficial the nation\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9csovereign democracy\xe2\x80\x9d may be, his popularity is enormous and real. Any politician would envy his association with stability, prosperity, security, restored imperial power and vigorous state authority.'b'It was always presumptuous to expect Russia, an ancient nation-state and proud empire of distinct culture with a tradition of autocracy, to become an Anglo-American democracy overnight \xe2\x80\x94 just as it is na\xc3\xafve to expect it in other parts of the world. The unspoken contract between ruler and subject is that in return for safety, prosperity and prestige, the Russians entrust power and cede democratic freedoms to their leaders.'b'Even under a regime dominated by former K.G.B. officials, Moscow is freer than at any time in its history, other than the mid-1990s. So it is astonishing that, while Russia has its own Vogue magazine and Internet cafes, its political process is now more arcane, more eccentric  and yet more public than it was during the 18th-century \xe2\x80\x9cage of palace revolutions.\xe2\x80\x9d The existence of Russia\xe2\x80\x99s democratic Constitution has led to far more smoke and mirrors than in China, where successions to a bureaucratic collective leadership are managed by a tiny camarilla in a self-declared one-party state.'b'The view of de Custine about  Russia  in the mid-19th century could easily apply to the 21st: \xe2\x80\x9cI came here to see a country, but what I find is a theater ... In appearances, everything happens as it does everywhere else. There is no difference except in the very foundation of things.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Russia has had a functioning system for handing over power for only 121 years in its entire history: during the later years of the Romanov autocracy. Before Emperor Paul I established a legal structure in 1797, there was no law of succession: Czars simply chose their heirs. Both Peter the Great and Ivan the Terrible undermined their own achievements by killing their sons and chosen heirs. After Peter\xe2\x80\x99s death in 1725, the succession was decided through 70 years of palace coups and regicide, a system oft described by the witty phrase \xe2\x80\x9cautocracy tempered by assassination.\xe2\x80\x9d Strong, intelligent empresses like Elizabeth and Catherine the Great seized power, creating an age of omnipotent petticoats.'b'Catherine, a German with no claim to the throne, in 1762 overthrew her own husband, Peter III, who was subsequently strangled by two courtiers, Aleksei Orlov and his brother Grigory (who was also Catherine\xe2\x80\x99s lover) in a drunken frenzy. The official announcement was that he had died of piles \xe2\x80\x94 prompting the French philosopher d\xe2\x80\x99Alembert to joke, when invited by Catherine to visit, that he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t go since he suffered from hemorrhoids, potentially fatal in Russia.'b'Catherine\xe2\x80\x99s heir, Paul I, so hated his mother that he created his law of strict male succession. He was a despotic, half-mad emperor with a fixation on military parades, and in 1801 was strangled and brained with an inkwell by his own courtiers. Yet his decision to codify the turnover of power ushered in an era of stable successions that lasted until 1917.'b'There was no succession rule in the Soviet state, an empire ruled by a murderous clique, men who met in paranoid secrecy as if they were still scruffy conspirators plotting in a room above some provincial tavern. Sovereignty in this institutionalized conspiracy was meant to rest in the Central Committee, but actually five or six magnates decided everything.'b'Regarding themselves as irreplaceable, both Lenin and Stalin tried in different ways to destroy their successors \xe2\x80\x94 Lenin through a testament that attacked Stalin and Trotsky, Stalin through purges culminating in the Doctors\xe2\x80\x99 Plot of 1953. The aftermaths in both cases were grim: all Lenin\xe2\x80\x99s potential heirs were  killed by Stalin, and the struggle after Stalin\xe2\x80\x99s death in 1953 was described by Winston Churchill as \xe2\x80\x9cbulldogs fighting under a rug.\xe2\x80\x9d At first the sadistic secret-police chief Lavrenti Beria emerged as strongman, until he was overthrown and shot in a plot hatched by Nikita Khrushchev.'b'Khrushchev, in turn, was overthrown in a palace coup in 1964 and pensioned off \xe2\x80\x94 though his successor, Leonid Brezhnev, considered having him killed. Brezhnev reigned into senility if not embalmment, followed by successions as sclerotically secretive as they were physically redundant. And so it continued through Mikhail Gorbachev, the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, the tumultuous reign of Boris Yeltsin and the steely paramountcy of Mr. Putin.'b'Vladimir Putin wants his successes in Russia to be respected by the West; hence he did not simply ignore the Constitution and stay in the presidency. He and his grandees  believe in the idiosyncratic style of authoritarian democracy  that has restored Russian prestige (although his courtiers are also keen to preserve their power and wealth).'b'Things could be worse: the neighboring former Soviet republics demonstrate the crasser solutions Russia rightly wishes to avoid. In Kazakhstan, the Constitution has been altered so President Nursultan Nazarbayev may reign endlessly. In Turkmenistan, the gruesomely dotty Sapamurat  Niyazov appointed himself president for life and took the name Turkmenbashi, \xe2\x80\x9cfather of All Turkmens.\xe2\x80\x9d Azerbaijan has effectively become a monarchy: on his death in 2003, President Heydar Aliyev (who had served in Brezhnev\xe2\x80\x99s Politburo) was succeeded by his son, Ilham \xe2\x80\x94 a surprising return of the hereditary principle also seen in other \xe2\x80\x9csocialist republics\xe2\x80\x9d including Syria (ruled by the Assad dynasty) and North Korea (the Kims).'b'If the Russians are happy with it, should their peculiar semi-modern, semi-medieval system concern us? A superb book called \xe2\x80\x9cFlawed Succession,\xe2\x80\x9d edited by Uri Ra\xe2\x80\x99anan in 2006,  examines four 20th-century Russian successions and suggests it does: \xe2\x80\x9cThe absence of a transparent, consistently implemented, non-arbitrary transfer of power mechanism,\xe2\x80\x9d writes Professor Ra\xe2\x80\x99anan, means that power is \xe2\x80\x9ctransferred inevitably by coups, whether through covert opaque manipulations ... or physical elimination.\xe2\x80\x9d Without such a mechanism, \xe2\x80\x9ca democracy cannot be established,\xe2\x80\x9d nor can rule of law or a civic society.'b'Clearly, this lack of civic society affects the way rulers rule. Russia is so feudal in its system of patronage and reward that it is virtually impossible for a leader to hand over power without controlling his successor or at least receiving an exemption from prosecution \xe2\x80\x94 something Mr. Putin granted his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, in 1999. Leaders, writes Professor Ra\xe2\x80\x99anan, \xe2\x80\x9care condemned to lead a Hobbesian existence, fearing the penalties that come with loss of power.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It matters because the whims of the system are reflected in Russia\xe2\x80\x99s lurchingly inconsistent foreign and military policies, which are unreadable to outsiders, from its war in Georgia last year to the current gas crisis with Ukraine. Are these accidents, adventures, opportunities, policies? And who is deciding them?'b'Yet a drop in its oil revenues could lead to domestic unrest \xe2\x80\x94 there is no other way to overthrow the oligarchy. Meanwhile, Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s succession and (likely) restoration is a leisurely dance of the seven veils in which one veil is dropped only for another to be donned \xe2\x80\x94 more fascinating even than the danse macabre of Soviet Kremlinology. But no one, probably not even the grandees of the Kremlin themselves, knows how it will end.'b'The Obama team is tight with information, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the scoop on the senior advisers he\xe2\x80\x99s gathered to push a new Middle East policy as the Gaza war rages: Shibley Telhami, Vali Nasr, Fawaz Gerges, Fouad Moughrabi and James Zogby.'b'This group of distinguished Arab-American and Iranian-American scholars, with wide regional experience, is intended to signal a U.S. willingness to think anew about the Middle East, with greater cultural sensitivity to both sides, and a keen eye on whether uncritical support for Israel has been helpful.'b'O.K., forget the above, I\xe2\x80\x99ve let my imagination run away with me. Barack Obama has no plans for this line-up on the Israeli-Palestinian problem and Iran.'b'In fact, the people likely to play significant roles on the Middle East in the Obama Administration read rather differently.'b'They include Dennis Ross (the veteran Clinton administration Mideast peace envoy who may now extend his brief to Iran); James Steinberg (as deputy secretary of state); Dan Kurtzer (the former U.S. ambassador to Israel); Dan Shapiro (a longtime aide to Obama); and Martin Indyk (another former ambassador to Israel who is close to the incoming secretary of state, Hillary Clinton.)'b'Now, I have nothing against smart, driven, liberal, Jewish (or half-Jewish) males; I\xe2\x80\x99ve looked in the mirror. I know or have talked to all these guys, except Shapiro. They\xe2\x80\x99re knowledgeable, broad-minded and determined. Still, on the diversity front they fall short. On the change-you-can-believe-in front, they also leave something to be desired.'b'In an adulatory piece in Newsweek, Michael Hirsh wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cRoss\xe2\x80\x99s previous experience as the indefatigable point man during the failed Oslo process, as well as the main negotiator with Syria, make him uniquely suited for a major renewal of U.S. policy on nearly every front.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Really? I wonder about the capacity for \xe2\x80\x9cmajor renewal\xe2\x80\x9d of someone who has failed for so long.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDo people in the region take note when Arab-Americans are not represented? Sure they do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Zogby, the president of the Arab American Institute in Washington. \xe2\x80\x9cA message gets sent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s important for Obama to get his message right from day one. With the Al Jazeera and Al Arabiya networks broadcasting 24-7 images of the carnage in Gaza, where there are more than 800 dead, mobilization in the Arab world is intense. Rage against Israel, and behind it America, bodes ill.'b'Change is needed, and not just in the intensity of U.S. diplomatic involvement with Israel-Palestine. Some fundamental questions must be asked.'b'Does regarding the Middle East almost exclusively through the prism of the war on terror make sense? Does turning a blind eye to the Israeli settlements in the West Bank that frustrate a two-state solution, and the Israeli blockade of Gaza that radicalizes its population, not undermine U.S. interest in bolstering moderate Palestinian sentiment?'b'Should policy not be directed toward reconciling a Palestinian movement now split between Fatah and Hamas, without which no final-status peace will be possible? Beyond their terrorist wings, in their broad grass-roots political movements, what elements of Hamas and Hezbollah can be coaxed toward the mainstream?'b'Do we understand the increasingly sophisticated Middle East of Al Jazeera where, as Telhami, a professor at the University of Maryland, put it to me, \xe2\x80\x9cPeople are not dumb and our credibility is at a historic near-zero?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Asking these questions does not alter America\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to Israel\xe2\x80\x99s security within its pre-1967 borders, which is and should be unwavering. It does not change the unacceptability of Hamas rockets or the fact the Hamas Charter is vile. But it would signal that the damaging Bush-era consensus that Israel can do no wrong is to be challenged.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel encouraged  \xe2\x80\x94  not by the putative Ross-redux team, nor by the nonbinding resolutions passed last week in the Senate and the House of Representatives. The former offered \xe2\x80\x9cunwavering commitment\xe2\x80\x9d to Israel. The latter recognized \xe2\x80\x9cIsrael\xe2\x80\x99s right to defend itself against attacks from Gaza.\xe2\x80\x9d Neither criticized Israel.'b'It seems that among liberal democracies, it is only in the U.S .Congress that a defense against terror that results in the slaying of hundreds of Palestinian children is not cause for agonized soul-searching. In my view, such Israeli \xe2\x80\x9cdefense\xe2\x80\x9d has crossed the line.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe are all opposed to terrorism,\xe2\x80\x9d Telhami said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut how does that enlighten you about how to move forward?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Enlightenment will require a fresher, broader Mideast team than Obama is contemplating. As noted in \xe2\x80\x9cNegotiating Arab-Israeli Peace: American Leadership in the Middle East,\xe2\x80\x9d a fine evaluation of U.S. diplomacy by Kurtzer and Scott Lasensky, the lack of expertise on Islam and an Arab perspective was costly at Camp David. At one point, the State Department\xe2\x80\x99s top Arabic translator had to be drafted because \xe2\x80\x9cthe lack of cross-cultural negotiating skills was so acute.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Obama should take note, name an Arab-American and an Iranian-American to prominent roles, and beware of a team that takes him  \xe2\x80\x94  and the region  \xe2\x80\x94  back to the future.'b'He said during the campaign that \xe2\x80\x9can unwavering pro-Likud approach to Israel\xe2\x80\x9d can\xe2\x80\x99t be \xe2\x80\x9cthe measure of our friendship with Israel.\xe2\x80\x9d Those were words. Now, with Gaza blood flowing, come deeds.'b'After the presidential election, the Republican National Committee filed a lawsuit that could drive a stake through the heart of the campaign finance system. It challenges the constitutionality of the McCain-Feingold law\xe2\x80\x99s ban on \xe2\x80\x9csoft money\xe2\x80\x9d contributions. If the suit succeeds, it will seriously damage democracy by allowing a virtually unlimited amount of corporate and other special-interest money to flood into politics.'b'There is no denying that the campaign finance system is badly broken. It suffered even more harm  when Barack Obama became the first major-party nominee to refuse  public financing and the spending limits that come with it. One of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s top priorities should be fixing the system\xe2\x80\x99s flaws, including  the core problem that it does not provide enough money for  a strong presidential campaign in modern times. But it will be impossible to fix the system if the R.N.C. prevails in court.'b'The Republicans are trying to remove the restrictions that McCain-Feingold puts on contributions to national political parties. Now, the parties are allowed to accept no more than $28,500 a year from individuals, and nothing at all from corporations or labor unions. The R.N.C. wants to strip away these restrictions so it can accept unlimited amounts of \xe2\x80\x9csoft,\xe2\x80\x9d or unrestricted, money from corporations and rich people.'b'The suit, which is before a special three-judge panel in Washington, claims that the limits are unconstitutional. The R.N.C. says it uses much of the money it raises for activities not related to federal elections, such as redistricting, grass-roots organizing and issue advertising. It argues that the First Amendment prohibits limiting contributions for these purposes.'b'The problem with this argument is that the Supreme Court  has already rejected it. In 2003, in McConnell v. F.E.C., the justices upheld the precise provisions the Republicans are now challenging.'b'In its ruling, the court emphasized that it does not matter what the money is spent on. Because the national parties have close ties to federal elected officials, the court said, large donations to the parties inject special-interest money into the federal government and have a corrupting effect on politics.'b'The McConnell decision should end the matter. But the R.N.C. seems to be hoping that because of changes in the court \xe2\x80\x94 in particular, Justice Sandra Day O\xe2\x80\x99Connor\xe2\x80\x99s replacement by Samuel Alito \xe2\x80\x94 it can persuade the court to undo this recent and important precedent.'b'The Republican Party\xe2\x80\x99s suit was clearly prompted by its troubles in the 2008 election, in which Mr. Obama proved far more adept at fund-raising than John McCain. It is disturbing that the R.N.C. sees its salvation in clearing the way for corporations and other special interests to flood its campaign coffers once again.'b'In its 2003 ruling, the Supreme Court declared that McCain-Feingold\xe2\x80\x99s limits on soft money were a permissible means \xe2\x80\x9cto confine the ill effects of aggregated wealth on\xe2\x80\x9d national politics. The courts should reaffirm that well-reasoned decision \xe2\x80\x94 and  Mr.  Obama and Congress should get to work fixing the current badly flawed, out-of-date campaign finance system.'b'The Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s recent decision not to award the Purple Heart to soldiers suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder strikes us as reasonable and well considered. This is not to say that the result was uncomplicated or unlikely to cause understandable sadness and pain.'b'The military has always honored the sacrifice of veterans who are wounded in its wars. But it has been slow to recognize that those wounds can include invisible injuries: the nightmares, rages and terrors of PTSD, which are as real as any scar or missing limb.'b'PTSD can be difficult to diagnose, with symptoms that can arise later in life, far from the battlefield and are not necessarily linked to any specific actions of an enemy. So the Pentagon contends that it has no choice but to exclude its sufferers from the Purple Heart, given to those whose injuries result from direct and  intentional action by the enemy. Doing so would not debase the medal, as some defenders of the Purple Heart callously put it, but it would change it, perhaps in unintended and unwelcome ways.'b'The main criterion for awarding the Purple Heart has always been bloodshed. Those looking for absolute fairness in this distinction will never find it: a soldier who cowers or blunders into harm\xe2\x80\x99s way will receive his medal just as surely as his quick-thinking, unscathed buddy will not. A soldier whose lacerations heal completely will wear the same medal as someone who has lost a limb or been paralyzed for life.'b'None of this relieves the military of its duty to fully honor those whose injuries are unseen. A Purple Heart may not be the answer \xe2\x80\x94 not until, perhaps, advances in brain science bring full objectivity to the diagnosis of mental injury. But PTSD sufferers surely deserve medical care every bit as diligent and excellent as what their fellow veterans receive for more visible injuries. The Pentagon has been prodded to do so by the deadly innovation of the current war: the bomb blasts that have exacted such a deadly toll in brain injuries.'b'The military is, in fact, moving forward merely by mentioning PTSD and the Purple Heart in the same breath. Imagine Gen. George Patton, who so notoriously slapped a quivering enlisted man, learning that his beloved Army was even considering giving medals to those whose combat tours left them mentally shattered.'b'But there is far more to do. Recent veterans of Iraq or Afghanistan will tell you that the military stigma against mental illness has not abated, that the combat ethos \xe2\x80\x94 suck it up, soldier \xe2\x80\x94 persists and that some officers continue to belittle the severity, and even question the existence, of post-traumatic stress.'b'At least 300,000  service members who were in  Afghanistan or Iraq show symptoms of PTSD. They  know a truth their forebears of Vietnam, Korea and World War II have lived with for years: war injures everyone it touches.'b'The Bush administration has decided that it will not issue final fuel-economy standards before it leaves office. It is not entirely clear why. The regulators may have run out of time, or the White House may have chosen not to inflict any last-minute pain on the automakers.'b'The standards would surely have been weaker than what the automakers are capable of achieving. The Obama administration now has a free hand to set its own standards that will save consumers money at the pump, reduce oil dependency and greenhouse gases, and help make the American car companies more competitive.'b'The 2007 energy bill required new cars and trucks to meet a fleetwide average of 35 miles per gallon by 2020, a 40 percent increase over today\xe2\x80\x99s average of 25 m.p.g. Congress intended this as a floor, not a ceiling, and ordered the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to write specific regulations.'b'Last May, as part of these regulations, the agency set an interim fleetwide standard of 31.6 m.p.g by 2015. This was initially praised for pushing carmakers more than halfway to the 2020 goal. The automakers have since suggested they can meet these goals without difficulty, while reputable studies have said they can do even better \xe2\x80\x94 at least as high as 35 m.p.g. by 2015, and 40 m.p.g. by 2020, with no changes in current technology.'b'During Congressional hearings last year on the automakers\xe2\x80\x99 troubles, General Motors and Ford provided production plans to show that they would make more fuel-efficient cars. The Obama administration should make such vehicles a condition of any future  help. No matter what Detroit does, the new administration must set much tougher fuel-economy standards.'b'On Christmas Eve, the conservative pundit Monica Crowley argued on Fox News that instead of  rescuing America from the Great Depression, Franklin Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s spending on public works made it worse. She insisted that this bizarre claim was confirmed by \xe2\x80\x9call kinds of studies and academic work.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The show\xe2\x80\x99s host backed her up. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gregg Jarrett, \xe2\x80\x9cI think historians pretty much agree on that.\xe2\x80\x9d In the same vein, a recent Wall Street Journal opinion piece said F.D.R. helped turn \xe2\x80\x9ca panic into the worst depression of modern times.\xe2\x80\x9d Now, as Congress begins to debate President-elect  Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s ambitious economic stimulus plan, this anti-New Deal talking point is popping up all over.'b'Conservatives have railed against the New Deal from the start. In 1934, H. L. Mencken was already decrying it as \xe2\x80\x9ca saturnalia of expropriation and waste.\xe2\x80\x9d When F.D.R. ran for re-election in 1936, a headline in William Randolph Hearst\xe2\x80\x99s newspapers insisted that \xe2\x80\x9cMoscow Backs Roosevelt.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But Americans were not  fooled. They knew  F.D.R. was on their side in a way that Herbert Hoover and his fellow free-marketers hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been. They could see first-hand the good that Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s jobs programs were doing for the Depression\xe2\x80\x99s victims and the slow but unmistakable improvements in the economy.'b'In the 1934 midterm elections, the voters delivered their first verdict on the New Deal, expanding the Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 margins in Congress. In 1936, F.D.R. won in a bigger landslide than he had four years earlier. By 1940, the Republican nominee, Wendell Willkie, was supporting much of Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s social welfare and regulatory regime.'b'Anti-New Deal rhetoric has never disappeared from American political life. When Barry Goldwater ran for president in 1964, he attacked President Dwight Eisenhower for having presided over a \xe2\x80\x9cdime store New Deal.\xe2\x80\x9d But in recent years, the attacks have heated up.'b'At the start of the Bush administration, conservatives talked openly about rolling back the New Deal. They were trying to unravel the regulatory state, including protections for workers, consumers and investors. They were also promoting a favorite cause of Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s: privatizing Social Security, the crown jewel of the New Deal.'b'These days the public is in no mood, given the high costs of deregulation in the mortgage industry and the Bernard Madoff scandal, for more talk about dismantling regulations and federal oversight. But today, the new focus is Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s stimulus package. If F.D.R.\xe2\x80\x99s New Deal spending made things worse, it follows that the Obama administration should not make the same mistake.'b'The anti-New Deal line is wrong as a matter of economics. F.D.R.\xe2\x80\x99s spending programs did help the economy and created millions of new jobs. The problem, we now know, is not that F.D.R. spent too much priming the pump, but rather that he spent too little. It was his decision to cut back on spending on New Deal programs that brought about a nasty recession in 1937-38.'b'The second problem is that the criticism overlooks the relief Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s programs brought to millions. When F.D.R. took office, unemployment was 25 percent, and families were losing their homes, living in shantytowns, even fighting one another for  food at garbage dumps.'b'The difference that the Civilian Conservation Corps, the Works Progress Administration and other New Deal public works programs made in people\xe2\x80\x99s lives is incalculable.'b'F.D.R.\xe2\x80\x99s labor secretary, Frances Perkins, described in her memoir what a relief job meant to an \xe2\x80\x9calmost deaf, elderly lawyer\xe2\x80\x9d she knew whose practice had failed. He had gotten a job as a caretaker at a small seaside park. \xe2\x80\x9cHe made little extra plantings,\xe2\x80\x9d she recalled, \xe2\x80\x9carranged charming paths and walks, acted as guide to visitors, supervised children\xe2\x80\x99s play.\xe2\x80\x9d When she saw him, she said, \xe2\x80\x9che would always ask me to take a message to the President \xe2\x80\x94 a message of gratitude for a job which paid him fifteen dollars a week and kept him from starving to death.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Congressional Republicans say Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s stimulus will cost too much, and that over time the economy will cure itself. They eat every day.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cFor Privacy\xe2\x80\x99s Sake, Risking Do-It-Yourself Abortion\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 5):'b'Throughout history, women have tried many ways to end an unwanted pregnancy. Your article underscores the fact that after 36 years of legal abortion, some women still struggle to obtain reproductive health care because they don\xe2\x80\x99t understand or trust the American medical system.'b'In my Washington Heights clinic in northern Manhattan, I see at least one patient every week who has tried to end a pregnancy on her own. Such ads stated that the product should not be used by married ladies. This was a code that the product could cause an abortion, thus telling women who wanted to end a pregnancy to buy the product.'b'On the other hand, this is the 21st century. 'b''b'To the Editor:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUrban Singapore Prepares to Gobble Up Its Last Village\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 4) was sad and depressing. Mr. Obama answered that he wants to hear ideas about \xe2\x80\x9chow to spend money efficiently and effectively to jump-start the economy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'O.K., I\xe2\x80\x99ll bite \xe2\x80\x94 although as I\xe2\x80\x99ll explain shortly, the \xe2\x80\x9cjump-start\xe2\x80\x9d metaphor is part of the problem.'b'First, Mr. Obama should scrap his proposal for $150 billion in business tax cuts, which would do little to help the economy. Ideally he\xe2\x80\x99d scrap the proposed $150 billion payroll tax cut as well, though I\xe2\x80\x99m aware that it was a campaign promise.'b'Money not squandered on ineffective tax cuts could be used to provide further relief to Americans in distress \xe2\x80\x94 enhanced unemployment benefits, expanded Medicaid and more. And why not get an early start on the insurance subsidies \xe2\x80\x94 probably running at $100 billion or more per year \xe2\x80\x94 that will be essential if we\xe2\x80\x99re going to achieve universal health care?'b'Mainly, though, Mr. Obama needs to make his plan bigger. To see why, consider a new report from his own economic team.'b'On Saturday, Christina Romer, the future head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Jared Bernstein, who will be the vice president\xe2\x80\x99s chief economist, released estimates of what the Obama economic plan would accomplish. Their report is reasonable and intellectually honest, which is a welcome change from the fuzzy math of the last eight years.'b'But the report also makes it clear that the plan falls well short of what the economy needs.'b'According to Ms. Romer and Mr. Bernstein, the Obama plan would have its maximum impact in the fourth quarter of 2010. Without the plan, they project, the unemployment rate in that quarter would be a disastrous 8.8 percent. Yet even with the plan, unemployment would be 7 percent \xe2\x80\x94 roughly as high as it is now.'b'After 2010, the report says, the effects of the economic plan would rapidly fade away. The job of promoting full recovery would, however, remain undone: the unemployment rate would still be a painful 6.3 percent in the last quarter of 2011.'b'Now, economic forecasting is an inexact science, to say the least, and things could turn out better than the report predicts. But they could also turn out worse. The report itself acknowledges that \xe2\x80\x9csome private forecasters anticipate unemployment rates as high as 11 percent in the absence of action.\xe2\x80\x9d And I\xe2\x80\x99m with Lawrence Summers, another member of the Obama economic team, who recently declared, \xe2\x80\x9cIn this crisis, doing too little poses a greater threat than doing too much.\xe2\x80\x9d Unfortunately, that principle isn\xe2\x80\x99t reflected in the current plan.'b'So how can Mr. Obama do more? By including a lot more public investment in his plan \xe2\x80\x94 which will be possible if he takes a longer view.'b'The Romer-Bernstein report acknowledges that \xe2\x80\x9ca dollar of infrastructure spending is more effective in creating jobs than a dollar of tax cuts.\xe2\x80\x9d It argues, however, that \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a limit on how much government investment can be carried out efficiently in a short time frame.\xe2\x80\x9d But why does the time frame have to be short?'b'As far as I can tell, Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s planners have focused on investment projects that will deliver their main jobs boost over the next two years. But since unemployment is likely to remain high well beyond that two-year window, the plan should also include longer-term investment projects.'b'And bear in mind that even a project that delivers its main punch in, say, 2011 can provide significant economic support in earlier years. If Mr. Obama drops the \xe2\x80\x9cjump-start\xe2\x80\x9d metaphor, if he accepts the reality that we need a multi-year program rather than a short burst of activity, he can create a lot more jobs through government investment, even in the near term.'b'Still, shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Obama wait for proof that a bigger, longer-term plan is needed? No. Right now the investment portion of the Obama plan is limited by a shortage of \xe2\x80\x9cshovel ready\xe2\x80\x9d projects, projects ready to go on short notice. A lot more investment can be under way by late 2010 or 2011 if Mr. Obama gives the go-ahead now \xe2\x80\x94 but if he waits too long before deciding, that window of opportunity will be gone.'b'One more thing: even with the Obama plan, the Romer-Bernstein report predicts an average unemployment rate of 7.3 percent over the next three years. That\xe2\x80\x99s a scary number, big enough to pose a real risk that the U.S. economy will get stuck in a Japan-type deflationary trap.'b'So my advice to the Obama team is to scrap the business tax cuts, and, more important, to deal with the threat of doing too little by doing more. And the way to do more is to stop talking about jump-starts and look more broadly at the possibilities for government investment.'b'Barack Obama made news Sunday  on ABC\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThis Week\xe2\x80\x9d: The White House dog will likely be a Labradoodle or a Portuguese water dog.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to say I\xe2\x80\x99m a little disappointed. Far more troublesome is the conventional assumption that the recession is a more or less classic business cycle that an infusion of cash through infrastructure projects and tax cuts will turn around. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t, and it won\xe2\x80\x99t be.'b'The current recession is not cyclical; it is structural, and it is unprecedented. During the 1930s, thousands of factories closed. But their buildings and equipment remained in place and intact, and they could be reactivated to meet World War II mobilization needs. That model no longer exists.'b'Most of the thousands of manufacturing facilities that closed since World War II closed for good. Their equipment was crated and shipped overseas; their buildings are boarded up, their workers laid off. These factories didn\xe2\x80\x99t close because of a cyclical shortfall in demand but because they lost their markets to imports.'b'No fiscal stimulus can possibly match the benefits of using low-wage overseas labor for such production. It found appalling failures to collect information and act on it.'b'The makers of drugs or medical devices are required to obtain financial information from the scientists conducting clinical trials before the trials start, consult with the F.D.A. to resolve serious conflicts and submit all the financial information to the F.D.A. when they apply for marketing approval after the trials end. The agency is supposed to evaluate whether any conflicts that are uncovered undermine the reliability of the trial data, and if so, how tainted data should be handled.'b'The inspector general found that fewer than 1 percent of the doctors who helped oversee clinical trials reported any financial conflicts \xe2\x80\x94 such as consulting payments, honoraria, grants, patents or stock options \xe2\x80\x94 that might influence their studies. That number seems unbelievably low given credible estimates that one-fifth to one-third of all doctors have such conflicts.'b'In 42 percent of the approved marketing applications, the agency did not receive all the required financial information, mostly because the sponsoring companies took advantage of a loophole that allowed them to say they had tried with due diligence to get the information from clinical investigators but were unable to. Even when the doctors did report significant conflicts to the companies, in 20 percent of the cases neither the F.D.A. nor the companies took action to minimize potential bias.'b'The inspector general made several suggestions, including stressing that the due diligence exemption should be used rarely. The agency accepted most, but it strongly opposed a recommendation that it require companies to submit financial conflict information before a clinical trial is started, not after it is completed. The F.D.A. complained that that would increase its workload for no clear gain, especially since many drugs or devices that enter clinical trials never reach the market.'b'Such bureaucratic excuses seem lame. Surely it would be better for the F.D.A. to eliminate potential conflicts before they can bias a trial than try to mitigate them after the results are in.'b'The agency\xe2\x80\x99s lax performance underscores the need for Congress to pass legislation requiring all drug and device makers to report their financial arrangements with doctors in a public databank. That would make it harder for clinical investigators or sponsoring companies to hide potential conflicts, including those that might bias clinical trials for the F.D.A.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cMoving Forward in Hard Times\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 8):'b'Gov. One irresistible reality grows from Hamas\xe2\x80\x99s complicated, competitive relationship with Hezbollah. For Hamas, Hezbollah is not only a source of weapons and instruction, it is a mentor and role model.'b'Hamas\xe2\x80\x99s desire to best Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s achievements is natural, of course, but, more to the point, it is radicalizing. Hamas and Hezbollah emerged from very different streams of Islam: Hamas is the Palestinian branch of the Sunni Muslim Brotherhood; Hezbollah is an outright Iranian proxy that takes its inspiration from the radical Shiite politics of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. But the groups share a common belief that Jews are a cosmological evil, enemies of  Islam since Muhammad sought refuge in Medina.'b'Periodically, advocates of negotiation suggest that the hostility toward Jews expressed by Hamas is somehow mutable. But in years of listening, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t heard much to suggest that its anti-Semitism is insincere. Like Hezbollah, Hamas believes that God is opposed to  a Jewish state in Palestine. Both groups are rhetorically pitiless, though, again, Hamas sometimes appears to follow the lead of Hezbollah.'b'I once asked Abdel Aziz Rantisi where he learned what he called \xe2\x80\x9cthe truth\xe2\x80\x9d of the Holocaust \xe2\x80\x94 that it didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen \xe2\x80\x94 and he referred me to books published by Hezbollah. The shout remains, \xe2\x80\x98Death to Israel!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Rayyan said that, technically, Mr. Nasrallah was mistaken. \xe2\x80\x9cAllah changed disobedient Jews into apes and pigs, it is true, but he specifically said these apes and pigs did not have the ability to reproduce,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Rayyan said. \xe2\x80\x9cSo it is not literally true that Jews today are descended from pigs and apes, but it is true that some of the ancestors of Jews were transformed into pigs and apes, and it is true that Allah continually makes the Jews pay for their crimes in many different ways. They are a cursed people.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I asked him the question I always ask of Hamas leaders: Could you agree to anything more than a tactical cease-fire with Israel? Mr. Rayyan answered the question as I thought he would, saying that a long-term cease-fire would be unnecessary, because it will not take long for the forces of Islam to eradicate Israel.'b'There is a fixed idea among some Israeli leaders that Hamas can be bombed into moderation. The fluid is then re-injected. The system forms a closed loop. It creates almost no emissions and is entirely renewable. It also occupies a smaller surface area than either solar or wind power.'b'Still, large-scale commercial production is at least a decade away and will require improvements on currently available technology. It\xe2\x80\x99s a mountain of festering refuse, a half-hour hike across, emitting clouds of smoke from subterranean fires.'b'The miasma of toxic stink leaves you gasping, breezes batter you with filth, and even the rats look forlorn. Then the smoke parts and you come across a child ambling barefoot, searching for old plastic cups that recyclers will buy for five cents a pound. Many families actually live in shacks on this smoking garbage.'b'Mr. Obama and the Democrats who favor labor standards in trade agreements mean well, for they intend to fight back at oppressive sweatshops abroad. But while it shocks Americans to hear it, the central challenge in the poorest countries is not that sweatshops exploit too many people, but that they don\xe2\x80\x99t exploit enough.'b'Talk to these families in the dump, and a job in a sweatshop is a cherished dream, an escalator out of poverty, the kind of gauzy if probably unrealistic ambition that parents everywhere often have for their children.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d love to get a job in a factory,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pim Srey Rath, a 19-year-old woman scavenging for plastic. \xe2\x80\x9cAt least that work is in the shade. Here is where it\xe2\x80\x99s hot.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another woman, Vath Sam Oeun, hopes her 10-year-old boy, scavenging beside her, grows up to get a factory job, partly because she has seen other children run over by garbage trucks. Her boy has never been to a doctor or a dentist, and last bathed when he was 2,  so a sweatshop job by comparison would be far more pleasant and less dangerous.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m glad that many Americans are repulsed by the idea of importing products made by barely paid, barely legal workers in dangerous factories. Yet sweatshops are only a symptom of poverty, not a cause, and banning them closes off one route out of poverty. At a time of tremendous economic distress and protectionist pressures, there\xe2\x80\x99s a special danger that  tighter labor standards will be used as an excuse to curb trade.'b'When I defend sweatshops, people always ask me: But would you want to work in a sweatshop? No, of course not. But I would want even less to pull a rickshaw. In the hierarchy of jobs in poor countries, sweltering at a sewing machine isn\xe2\x80\x99t the bottom.'b'My views on sweatshops are shaped by years living in East Asia, watching as living standards soared \xe2\x80\x94 including those in my wife\xe2\x80\x99s ancestral village in southern China \xe2\x80\x94 because of sweatshop jobs.'b'Manufacturing is one sector that can provide millions of jobs. Yet sweatshops usually go not to the poorest nations but to better-off countries with more reliable electricity and ports.'b'I often hear the argument: Labor standards can improve wages and working conditions, without greatly affecting the eventual retail cost of goods. That\xe2\x80\x99s true. But labor standards and \xe2\x80\x9cliving wages\xe2\x80\x9d have a larger impact on production costs that companies are always trying to pare. The result is to push companies to operate more capital-intensive factories in better-off nations like Malaysia, rather than labor-intensive factories in poorer countries like Ghana or Cambodia.'b'Cambodia has, in fact, pursued an interesting experiment by working with factories to establish decent labor standards and wages. It\xe2\x80\x99s a worthwhile idea, but one result of paying above-market wages is that those in charge of hiring often demand bribes \xe2\x80\x94 sometimes a month\xe2\x80\x99s salary \xe2\x80\x94 in exchange for a job. In addition, these standards add to production costs, so some factories have closed because of the global economic crisis and the difficulty of competing internationally.'b'The best way to help people in the poorest countries isn\xe2\x80\x99t to campaign against sweatshops but to promote manufacturing there. One of the best things America could do for Africa would be to strengthen our program to encourage African imports, called AGOA, and nudge Europe to match it.'b'Among people who work in development, many strongly believe (but few dare say very loudly) that one of the best hopes for the poorest countries would be to build their manufacturing industries. But global campaigns against sweatshops make that less likely.'b'Look, I know that Americans have a hard time accepting that sweatshops can help people. She\xe2\x80\x99s wearing a \xe2\x80\x9cPlayboy\xe2\x80\x9d shirt and hat that she found amid the filth, and she worries about her sister, who lost part of her hand when a garbage truck ran over her.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s dirty, hot and smelly here,\xe2\x80\x9d she said wistfully. \xe2\x80\x9cA factory is better.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Eric Holder, President-elect Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s nominee for attorney general, is scheduled to appear today at a confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee. Not that we are so different from one another, but that we are so alike.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Once there was just Newtonian physics and the world seemed neat and mechanical. Then quantum physics came along and revealed that deep down things are much weirder than they seem. Something similar is now happening with public policy.'b'Once, classical economics dominated policy thinking. The classical models presumed a certain sort of orderly human makeup. Inside each person, reason rides the passions the way a rider sits atop a horse. Sometimes people do stupid things, but generally the rider makes deliberative decisions, and the market rewards rational behavior.'b'Markets tend toward efficiency. People respond in pretty straightforward ways to incentives. The invisible hand forms a spontaneous, dynamic order. Economic behavior can be accurately predicted through elegant models.'b'This view explains a lot, but not the current financial crisis \xe2\x80\x94 how so many people could be so stupid, incompetent and self-destructive all at once. The crisis has delivered a blow to classical economics and taken a body of psychological work that was at the edge of public policy thought and brought it front and center.'b'In this new body of thought, you get a very different picture of human nature. Reason is not like a rider atop a horse. Instead, each person\xe2\x80\x99s mind contains a panoply of instincts, strategies, intuitions, emotions, memories and habits, which vie for supremacy. An irregular, idiosyncratic and largely unconscious process determines which of these internal players gets to control behavior at any instant. Context \xe2\x80\x94 which stimulus triggers which response \xe2\x80\x94 matters a lot.'b'This mental chaos explains how people can respond so quickly and intuitively to so many different circumstances. But it also entails a decision-making process that is more complicated and messy than previously thought.'b'For example, we don\xe2\x80\x99t perceive circumstances objectively. We pick out those bits of data that make us feel good because they confirm our prejudices. As Andrew Lo of M.I.T. has demonstrated, if stock traders make a series of apparently good picks, the dopamine released into their brains creates a stupor that causes them to underperceive danger ahead.'b'Biases abound. People who\xe2\x80\x99ve been told to think of a high number will subsequently bid much more for an item than people who\xe2\x80\x99ve been told to think of a low number. As Jonah Lehrer writes in his forthcoming book, \xe2\x80\x9cHow We Decide,\xe2\x80\x9d there are certain circumstances (often when there are many options) in which gut instincts lead to the best decisions, while there are other circumstances (sometimes when there are a few options) when calm deliberation is best.'b'Most important, people seek relationships more than money. If behaving a certain way helps a stock trader or a regulator fit in with his crowd, he\xe2\x80\x99s likely to keep doing it without too much rigorous self-examination.'b'A thousand mental shortcomings contributed to the financial meltdown. But that only explains a piece of what\xe2\x80\x99s happening.'b'This crisis represents a flaw in the classical economic model and its belief in efficient markets. You can run up gigantic deficits, hire road builders and reduce the unemployment rate from 8 percent to 7 percent, but insecure people will still not spend and invest.'b'The economic spirit of a people cannot be manipulated in as simple-minded a fashion as the Keynesian mechanists imagine. The result was a meaningful dilution of Americans\xe2\x80\x99 Fourth Amendment protections and one more instance of the court\xe2\x80\x99s conservative majority upsetting precedent without admitting that it is doing so.'b'The case centered on the 2004 arrest of Bennie Dean Herring by police officers in Coffee County, Ala., based on a mistaken belief that he was the subject of an outstanding warrant. Before approving the settlement, the courts will have to decide if the amounts agreed to are enough.'b'Typically, when patients use non-network doctors, their insurance company agrees to pay 70 percent to 80 percent of the \xe2\x80\x9creasonable and customary\xe2\x80\x9d charges for a given medical service in the same geographic area. If the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s bill is higher than that rate, the patient must make up the difference or the doctor must settle for less.'b'The rub comes in defining what is reasonable and customary.'b'That calculation for most of the industry is made by a company called Ingenix, which conveniently is owned by UnitedHealth. The whole system is rendered suspect by an obvious conflict of interest: If Ingenix pegs the customary rates low, it keeps insurance reimbursements low and shifts more of the cost to the patient.'b'Investigators for Mr. Cuomo contend that UnitedHealth and Ingenix have been manipulating the data through a variety of stratagems to keep the customary rate calculation low \xe2\x80\x94 and the insurance payments low.'b'Based on their own data collection and calculations, the investigators estimated that insurers have systematically underpaid New Yorkers for medical services by 10 percent to 28 percent, depending on where they lived.'b'UnitedHealth neither admits nor denies any wrongdoing, but the company does acknowledge the inherent conflict of interest and is paying substantially to put the issue to rest.'b'As a result of the agreement, future reimbursements should be less subject to manipulation and a lot more transparent. UnitedHealth is planning to close its Ingenix databases and shift responsibility to an independent nonprofit organization \xe2\x80\x94 possibly a university-level school of public health \xe2\x80\x94 that will be the sole arbiter of data collection and calculation methodologies.'b'UnitedHealth will contribute $50 million to help get the new system operating. It has been a long time coming.'b''b'When President-elect Barack Obama and his family move into the White House on Tuesday, they will be joined by Michelle Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 71-year-old mother, Marian Robinson. Some commentators have relished not just the novelty of the situation, but its sitcom possibilities \xe2\x80\x94 the most powerful man in the world living with his mother-in-law! But the White House has always been home to many different kinds of families, all of whom re-invented the place to fit their needs. The drawings below show how four presidents \xe2\x80\x94 Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, James Garfield and Franklin D. Roosevelt \xe2\x80\x94 lived and worked in the White House.'b''b'View all drawings 'b' here.'b''b'Thomas Jefferson never liked the White House: too big, too grand for the American president. He was determined to suggest \xe2\x80\x9crepublican\nsimplicity\xe2\x80\x9d and this mainly involved rearranging furniture. For instance, what his predecessor John Adams had used as a formal\nreception room \xe2\x80\x94 today\xe2\x80\x99s State Dining Room \xe2\x80\x94 Jefferson turned into his office, crowding the lofty space with books from his library,\ntrunks filled with files and a long table with many drawers, into which Jefferson personally sorted his correspondence. In 1801,\nwhen Jefferson moved in, parts of the house were still unfinished, including most of the second-floor family quarters, and he spent\nmuch of his time on the White House\xe2\x80\x99s main floor.'b'\xe2\x80\x94 WILLIAM SEALE, the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe President\xe2\x80\x99s House\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In Abraham Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s White House, there were few private spaces \xe2\x80\x94 just the family\xe2\x80\x99s bedrooms and library scrunched into the west\nside of the second floor. In the rest of the house, Secretary of State William Seward reported, \xe2\x80\x9cthe grounds, halls, stairways, closets\xe2\x80\x9d\nwere always overrun with hundreds of people, standing in long, winding lines and waving their letters of introduction in desperate\nhope of securing a job. When Lincoln was told he was wasting too much time listening to these ordinary people, he said: \xe2\x80\x9cI must see\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d These are my \xe2\x80\x9cpublic opinion baths,\xe2\x80\x9d insisted the president.'b'\xe2\x80\x94 DORIS KEARNS GOODWIN, the author of \xe2\x80\x9cTeam of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln\xe2\x80\x9d'b'James Garfield and his young family moved in on Inauguration Day, March 1881. He was shot in July at the Washington railroad depot\nand, wounded, was returned to the presidential bedroom, where the doctors were perplexed as to how to help him. Navy engineers\nwere assigned the task of keeping the president cool, it being a scorching summer. They tried ice, fans, every device imaginable.\nAt last a solution was proposed: an electric fan would blow through curtains of wetted cheesecloth into tin ducts borrowed from a\nheating system. The noise was unbearable but the invention worked. The temperature could even be adjusted, thus demonstrating\nthe feasibility of air-conditioning for the first time. In September, Garfield was moved to Elberon, N.J., where he died. The White\nHouse, which had already been undergoing a remodeling, was left a disaster, with air cooling equipment strung up the open stairwell\nand down the halls and nearly every room in disarray.'b'\xe2\x80\x94 W.S.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe live here as a big family in the greatest intimacy and informality,\xe2\x80\x9d Winston Churchill wrote of Franklin D. Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s White\nHouse. This intimacy is best illustrated thusly: In December 1941, Roosevelt awakened one morning with the idea of calling the Allies\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cUnited Nations.\xe2\x80\x9d Excited, he had himself wheeled into Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom \xe2\x80\x94 just as Churchill was emerging from the tub with\nabsolutely nothing on. The president apologized and started to leave. No need to go, Churchill said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe prime minister of Great\nBritain has nothing to conceal from the president of the United States!\xe2\x80\x9d During the Clinton administration, my husband and I were\ninvited to sleep at the White House. To my great delight we were given Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s room \xe2\x80\x94 but sleep never came that night, for I kept\nimagining Churchill standing in the center of the room as naked as the day he was born.'b'\xe2\x80\x94 D.K.G.'b'The cornucopia of hybrid and electric vehicles showcased at the North American International Auto Show this week suggests that the nation\xe2\x80\x99s automakers \xe2\x80\x94 domestic and transplanted \xe2\x80\x94 have finally acknowledged the need to deliver the fuel-efficient cars and trucks for a future of expensive gas and increasing environmental pressures.'b'But a big obstacle remains to the greening of American drivers: the price tag. With gas prices likely to remain low as consumers grapple with recession, drivers are going to need extra motivation to swap their gas gluttons for the novel, environmentally friendly cars and trucks. If the incoming Obama administration is serious about its commitment to boost the fuel efficiency of the American fleet, it must put in place a mix of policies, beyond tightening fuel-economy standards for carmakers, to steer drivers to the new cars.'b'The price of Ford\xe2\x80\x99s new hybrid Fusion sedan, estimated to travel a whopping 41 miles per gallon in the city, is expected to start at more than $27,000. The Volt, General Motors\xe2\x80\x99s high-profile plug-in car, could cost as much as $40,000. There are cheaper paths to environmental virtue: The Toyota Prius starts at only $22,000. And Honda\xe2\x80\x99s Insight hybrid \xe2\x80\x94 to go on sale later this year \xe2\x80\x94  is expected to cost less.'b'Still, with gas below $2 a gallon and recession-ravaged consumers hanging tight to their wallets, even the cheaper hybrids have to compete with cars that run on boring old internal combustion engines. The Prius was the flavor of the month when gas prices soared to $4. But in December, Prius sales plummeted 45 percent compared with the same month a year earlier \xe2\x80\x94 more than the 36 percent drop in all car sales.'b'Do the math. At $1.66 a gallon, the average gas price assumed in the government\xe2\x80\x99s 2009 energy guide, a hybrid Toyota Camry would only save the average driver about $250 a year in gas, compared with the regular Camry. But the hybrid costs $7,000 more.'b'A hefty gas tax would, of course, produce a strong incentive for drivers to switch to more fuel-efficient cars. But confronting a staggering economy, the Obama administration would be right to look for other options in the immediate future. The modest tax rebates offered to jump-start sales of hybrids and plug-ins starting in 2005 already have been phased out for the more popular models made by Honda and Toyota \xe2\x80\x94 and are slated to disappear entirely at the end of next year.'b'These rebates could be extended and increased. Ideally, they would be available to buyers of any car that achieved big improvements in energy efficiency, not just hi-tech vehicles. Another, more aggressive option floated last year by Alan Blinder, an economist at Princeton, would be for the government to buy up the most polluting and gas-hogging clunkers from American drivers and scrap them. That is an idea that has been tested in several states.'b'These ideas would fit neatly into an economic stimulus strategy, the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s effort to save Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s carmakers and its stated environmental objectives. Just hoping that American drivers will buy the fuel-efficient cars that the government wants Detroit to make is likely to achieve little.'b'The war in Afghanistan has been so disastrously mismanaged that some NATO allies \xe2\x80\x94 eager to shed their commitment \xe2\x80\x94 are arguing that it is too late to salvage. Like what the chances are that the next time you get on a plane, geese could fly into both engines. Or what the heck geese are doing in New York in the middle of winter when their relatives who worked hard and played by the rules had all gone south months ago.'b'Or you may just be wondering how that rescue in the Hudson River would have gone if it had been led off by the Department of Homeland Security rather than New York Waterway\xe2\x80\x99s director of ferry operations.'b'I can\xe2\x80\x99t help you, people. Today I am on inauguration duty.'b'While there is some debate about the best inaugural address in history, it\xe2\x80\x99s pretty clear that the worst was the one delivered by William Henry Harrison, who went thwacking through a tangled thicket of classical allusions for an hour and 45 minutes. (Harrison\xe2\x80\x99s editor, Daniel Webster, claimed it could have been worse, and that he had killed off \xe2\x80\x9cseventeen Roman proconsuls, as dead as smelts.\xe2\x80\x9d) The weather was terrible; Harrison came down with a cold, then pneumonia and was dead within a month.'b'Given current beaten-down expectations, our normal approach to Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s address would be to wander around muttering \xe2\x80\x9cwell as long as it\xe2\x80\x99s better than William Henry Harrison\xe2\x80\x99s...\xe2\x80\x9d But Barack Obama is a celebrated speaker, and our hopes are unusually high. So where are you going to be when it all happens? The options are many, including:'b'1. 'b'Go to Washington with the rest of the world.'b''b'For the nonelite, seeing the inauguration in Washington involves standing on the Mall, shivering and staring at a JumboTron in the company of many, many, many brand-new new acquaintances. Not everyone thinks this is the perfect way to experience history. Obama himself has been delicately hinting that we all might want to consider staying home, mentioning \xe2\x80\x9clong lines, a tough time getting around and most of all a lot of walking on what could be a very cold winter day.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Still, if you go, then you can always say you did. \xe2\x80\x9cActually having been there does give you some street cred, so to speak,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jeremy Brooke Straughn, a sociologist at Purdue University, who has done research on generational memory. This is not the kind of story that is going to leave them spellbound at your next dinner party.'b'But I totally sympathize. The first inauguration I went to was Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s in 1993 and the only thing I can remember is watching Barney the purple dinosaur vamp down Pennsylvania Avenue during the parade.'b''b'2. Join other Obama supporters for an inauguration party.'b''b'To find the nearest one, you can check 'b'my.barackobama.com'b'.
