Memory experts say that this sort of thing happens all the time, and the number of Americans who think they were at Woodstock, or watched the Red Sox win the World Series or marched on Washington with Martin Luther King Jr. is far, far greater than the number of actual attendees.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI almost feel like I was there for the \xe2\x80\x98I Have a Dream\xe2\x80\x99 speech, given how many times I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen it on TV,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Mueller of Ohio State University. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the number of people who saw that plane floating in the Hudson is probably already a lot higher than is possible.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Virtual attendance: a great way to experience history without leaving the comfort of your own home. (By the way, I work in an office near the Hudson River and am already beginning to remember watching the rescue even though our view was completely blocked by several big buildings. And there may have been a moment after the inauguration in 1993 when Barney and I went clubbing.)'b'All this is good news for people who did not vote for Obama but now yearn to have a part in the inaugural events. If you go to Washington, you will be welcomed by happy Obamites wearing name tags and fleece jackets. Even if you don\xe2\x80\x99t, you may gradually begin to remember that when you went to the polls, you pulled the Democratic lever. And if the new president does well and manages to resurrect the economy, by 2011 you will clearly recall doing door-to-door canvassing last September in a Yes We Can T-shirt.'b'If you want to see hell on earth, go to Zimbabwe where the madman Robert Mugabe has brought the country to such a state of ruin that medical care for most of the inhabitants has all but ceased to exist.'b'Life expectancy in Zimbabwe is now the lowest in the world:  37 years for men and 34 for women. A cholera epidemic is raging. People have become ill with anthrax after eating the decaying flesh of animals that had died from the disease. Power was lost to the morgue in the capital city of Harare, leaving the corpses to rot.'b'Most of the world is ignoring the agony of Zimbabwe, a once prosperous and medically advanced nation in southern Africa that is suffering from political and economic turmoil \xe2\x80\x94 and the brutality of Mugabe\xe2\x80\x99s long and tyrannical reign.'b'The decline in health services over the past year has been staggering. An international team of doctors that conducted an \xe2\x80\x9cemergency assessment\xe2\x80\x9d of the state of medical care last month seemed stunned by the catastrophe they witnessed. The team was sponsored by Physicians for Human Rights. In their report, released this week, the doctors said:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe collapse of Zimbabwe\xe2\x80\x99s health system in 2008 is unprecedented in scale and scope. Public-sector hospitals have been shuttered since November 2008. The basic infrastructure for the maintenance of public health, particularly water and sanitation services, have abruptly deteriorated in the worsening political and economic climate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Doctors and nurses are trying to do what they can under the most harrowing of circumstances: facilities with no water, no functioning toilets and barely any medicine or supplies. The report quoted the director of a mission hospital:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA major problem is the loss of life and fetal wastage we are seeing with obstetric patients. They come so late, the fetuses are already dead. We see women with eclampsia who have been seizing for 12 hours. There is no intensive care unit here, and now there is no intensive care in Harare.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf we had intensive care, we know it would be immediately full of critically ill patients. As it is, they just die.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mugabe\xe2\x80\x99s corrupt, violent and profoundly destructive reign has left Zim-babwe in shambles. It\xe2\x80\x99s a nation overwhelmed by poverty, the H.I.V./AIDS pandemic and hyperinflation. Once considered the \xe2\x80\x9cbreadbasket\xe2\x80\x9d of Africa, Zimbabwe is now a country that cannot feed its own people. The unemployment rate is higher than 80 percent. Malnutrition is widespread, as is fear.'b'A nurse told the Physicians for Human Rights team: \xe2\x80\x9cWe are not supposed to have hunger in Zimbabwe. So even though we do see it, we cannot report it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mugabe signed a power-sharing agreement a few months ago with a political opponent, Morgan Tsvangirai, who out-polled Mugabe in an election last March but did not win a majority of the votes. But continuing turmoil, including violent attacks by Mugabe\xe2\x80\x99s supporters and allegations that Mugabe forces have engaged in torture, have prevented the agreement from taking effect.'b'The widespread skepticism that greeted Mugabe\xe2\x80\x99s alleged willingness to share power only increased when he ranted, just last month: \xe2\x80\x9cI will never, never, never surrender ...  Zimbabwe is mine.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Meanwhile, health care in Zimbabwe has fallen into the abyss. \xe2\x80\x9cThis emergency is so grave that some entity needs to step in there and take over the health delivery system,\xe2\x80\x9d said Susannah Sirkin, the deputy director of Physicians for Human Rights.'b'In November, the primary public referral hospital in Harare, Parirenyatwa Hospital, shut down. Its medical school closed with it. The nightmare that forced the closings was spelled out in the report:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe hospital had no running water since August of 2008. Toilets were overflowing, and patients and staff had nowhere to void  \xe2\x80\x94  soon making the hospital uninhabitable. Parirenyatwa Hospital was closed four months into the cholera epidemic, arguably the worst of all possible times to have shut down public hospital access. Successful cholera care, treatment and control are impossible, however, in a facility without clean water and functioning toilets.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The hospital\xe2\x80\x99s surgical wards were closed in September. A doctor described the heartbreaking dilemma of having children in his care who he knew would die without surgery. \xe2\x80\x9cI have no pain medication,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9csome antibiotics, but no nurses ... If I don\xe2\x80\x99t operate, the patient will die. But if I do the surgery, the child will die also.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s documented in the Physicians for Human Rights report is evidence of a shocking medical and human rights disaster that warrants a much wider public spotlight, and an intensified effort to mount an international humanitarian intervention.'b'Some organizations are already on the case, including Doctors Without Borders and Unicef. But Zimbabwe is dying, and much more is needed.'b''b'We are shaped by the places we have lived. And Barack Obama has lived in a lot of different places. His memoir, \xe2\x80\x9cDreams From  My Father,\xe2\x80\x9d recounts formative years spent in Indonesia; Honolulu; Los Angeles; New York City; Cambridge, Mass.; and Chicago. How might these places have helped to mold the man who will be the next president of the United States? What might he have taken away from, say, Jakarta in 1967? Or Columbia University? Six writers who lived where Mr. Obama lived \xe2\x80\x94when he lived there \xe2\x80\x94 reflect on those questions.'b''b''b''b''b''b'In a long series of valedictory speeches and interviews, President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney have been crowing about Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay, secret prisons and abusive interrogations, claiming they met the highest legal standards and that no prisoner had been tortured. Fortunately, the truth broke through the noise, in the words of some of the very people ordered to carry out the policies.'b'In an interview in The Washington Post, Susan Crawford, the retired judge who runs the military tribunals at Guant\xc3\xa1namo, said that harsh interrogation methods had endangered the life of Mohammed al-Qahtani, a Saudi national accused of planning to take part in the 9/11 attacks. Authorized by then-Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, they included sustained isolation, nudity and prolonged exposure to the cold.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe tortured Qahtani,\xe2\x80\x9d Judge Crawford said, adding that she was therefore unable to prosecute a man who seemed to pose a real threat to the United States.'b'Judge Crawford was not the only one speaking out. Major David Frakt of the Air Force Reserve, who was assigned to defend another Guant\xc3\xa1namo prisoner, told MSNBC\xe2\x80\x99s Rachel Maddow that he and all the other defense lawyers in the system consider the tribunals \xe2\x80\x9cunfair, rigged\xe2\x80\x9d and unconstitutional. He noted that his client\xe2\x80\x99s prosecutor resigned to protest the lack of evidence in the case.'b'That is the real nature of Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s grotesque legacy: abuse and torture at an outlaw prison where hundreds of men \xe2\x80\x94 many of whom did nothing \xe2\x80\x94 have been held for years without real evidence or charges. And truly dangerous men were treated so badly that it may be impossible to bring them to justice.'b'\xc2\x95'b'It will be hard enough to close down Guant\xc3\xa1namo as Barack Obama has vowed to do, but the legal burdens Mr. Bush is dumping on his successor are much greater.'b'The appalling Military Commissions Act of 2006, railroaded through Congress, must be repealed. Interrogation rules that respect American values and laws and the Geneva Conventions must be set for all government agencies, including the intelligence agencies.'b'And there is the profound question of whether the new administration should prosecute those who tortured and abused prisoners \xe2\x80\x94 and those who ordered them to do it. Judge Crawford\xe2\x80\x99s legal finding that torture occurred adds a new complication, since a treaty obliges the United States to investigate such allegations.'b'We have heard a lot of talk about how the country needs to look forward and not backward. We certainly would like to forget the horrors of the last eight years. But you cannot fix something before you know exactly how it is broken. The clandestine system Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney have built will not give up its secrets easily.'b'To ensure that the abuses stop, Mr. Obama and his administration will have to work hard to find out all that has happened. They will have to locate and override all of the policy memos, directives and executive orders that have redefined and condoned torture and other abuses. Guant\xc3\xa1namo is the place to begin.'b''b'The timetable: 'b'Mr. Obama is expected to announce as early as Wednesday that he is beginning the process of shutting Guant\xc3\xa1namo. We hope he sets a target date. That may make it easier to persuade other governments to agree to accept some prisoners \xe2\x80\x94 one of the difficult challenges ahead. But we do not agree with critics who insist that date must fall within his first 100 days.'b'This page called early and often for closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo. But we recognize that this is going to be very hard work.'b''b'Sorting out the inmates: 'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers will have to review every file, most of which the Bush administration has refused to turn over to any authority, including Congress. We know from bitter experience that the Bush administration\xe2\x80\x99s judgment is worthless when it comes to what these prisoners may have done, how they have been treated and what justice they should face.'b'Just last week, Mr. Cheney claimed that the interrogation of prisoners like Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, believed to be the planner of 9/11, who was tortured by waterboarding, allowed the United States to capture a \xe2\x80\x9cvery impressive\xe2\x80\x9d list of Al Qaeda leaders in 2003. If that is true, Mr. Obama needs to know who they are, where they are, and what was done to them in the last five years.'b''b'A blueprint: 'b'Senator Dianne Feinstein, the new head of the Intelligence Committee, has a bill for closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo that Mr. Obama should embrace. It sets a one-year deadline and requires that every prisoner either be charged and tried in United States federal court; transferred for trial by an international tribunal under United Nations authority; returned to the custody of the government of their homeland, if that government does not abuse and torture prisoners; held as a prisoner of war; or, simply, released.'b'The separate system of tribunals created by the military commissions act must be abolished. They are a mockery of American justice, and utterly unnecessary.'b'It was extremely encouraging to hear Eric Holder, Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s choice for attorney general, say  at his confirmation hearing on Thursday that the new administration is open to trying prisoners in the United States. It is appalling that an attorney general nominee has to say he respects the law, but such is the Bush legacy.'b''b'The real bad guys: 'b'After the prisoners are sorted out, Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s egregiously bad judgment leaves all Americans with a huge problem. The abuses authorized by top Bush officials, and so gleefully defended by Mr. Cheney in particular in the last few weeks, create the possibility that men like Mohammed al-Qahtani and Khalid Shaikh Mohammed will never be able to face justice in a real courtroom.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s team will have to come up with a solution that does not set such men free. We are not sure what it should be, but there is one unacceptable choice: creating a new detentions law that would allow them held without trial. That would merely compound Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s catastrophically bad choices.'b''b'Interrogations: 'b'The 2006 military tribunals law bound military interrogators to the Army field manual\xe2\x80\x99s rules, which conform with the Geneva Conventions \xe2\x80\x94 unlike Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s policies. But, at Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s insistence, the bill carved out an exemption that allowed intelligence agencies to go on hiring civilian interrogators and to engage in practices that are clearly immoral and illegal. Ms. Feinstein\xe2\x80\x99s bill would eliminate the loophole on how prisoners are treated and ban the use of civilian interrogators.'b'We were glad to hear Mr. Holder state that the Obama administration considers the Geneva Conventions binding. But we wish he had been more clear on a solution, beyond calling the Army field manual a \xe2\x80\x9cgood start\xe2\x80\x9d for interrogation rules in C.I.A. prisons. We also were unclear from his answers whether Mr. Obama has decided, as he should, to ban civilian interrogators.'b'Mr. Holder unequivocally declared waterboarding to be torture, which his predecessors would not do. But this is not just about waterboarding. Other practices, like forced nudity, prolonged isolation, and extremes of heat and cold, are abuses under the same laws and treaties that prohibit torture. And Judge Crawford reminded us that torture is not necessarily just one terrible act. In the Qahtani case, she said: \xe2\x80\x9cThis was not any one particular act; this was just a combination of things that had a medical impact on him, that hurt his health. It was abusive and uncalled for. And coercive. Clearly coercive.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'C.I.A. prisons: 'b'We have never heard a convincing explanation for why the Central Intelligence Agency needs its own network of prisons beyond the reach of law, in undisclosed locations. If there is a good reason, we hope this administration will explain it. We are skeptical, and we urge Mr. Obama to support Ms. Feinstein\xe2\x80\x99s bill, which would require the C.I.A. to report all detainees to the International Committee of the Red Cross.'b'\xc2\x95'b'We recognize that this is a daunting agenda, and that to succeed, Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s White House, Justice Department and Pentagon will also have to rebuild demoralized legal divisions where professionals were replaced with apparatchiks whose mission was to twist the law to justify their masters\xe2\x80\x99 decisions.'b'This work is essential to restoring the rule of law. It is essential to restoring this country\xe2\x80\x99s reputation around the world. And it is essential to restoring Americans\xe2\x80\x99 faith in themselves and in their government. That is the only way to move forward.'b'When the thermometer bottoms out, I remember, again, that winter isn\xe2\x80\x99t a season, it\xe2\x80\x99s a place. Just over the hill is the 19th  century, and somewhere beyond the river lies the 18th.  Why winter should seem so much more continuous with the past than summer does is never clear to me. But this morning it\xe2\x80\x99s 3 degrees, and I can hear Melville, a few miles north of where I am, writing to his sister: \xe2\x80\x9cThe weather here has been as cold as ever. Other than the weather I know not what to write about from Pittsfield.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s how it feels in the neighborhood of zero. There is no \xe2\x80\x9cother than the weather.\xe2\x80\x9d I feed the woodstove, keep the diesel pickup plugged in, and admire the fortitude of the crows. On the reservoirs, a couple of Canada geese walk along the edge of the ice as though they were lifeguards. The rivers \xe2\x80\x94 all but the Hudson \xe2\x80\x94 dwindle to a narrow sluice of dark water. It takes an effort to remember that the water, which looks so bitterly cold, is the warmest element in the landscape.'b'As dusk comes, the temporal illusion seems to gain strength. The snowmobile tracks that cross the fields fade, and I imagine a huddled figure coming through the trees and stumping down the hill as if he had walked right out of the distant past and was making his way toward the lights of this house. The smoke from the chimney smells completely familiar to him, whatever century he comes from. And about then in my private storytelling, I remember that I\xe2\x80\x99m living in the warmer, brighter future that everyone in the country of winter has always aspired to.'b'A couple of nights ago, dusk brought a different illusion. The clouds had been hammered flat. But in the last few moments of afternoon, the sun slid below the overcast, coming out strong and red along the rim of the horizon. It brought no real warmth. But I could not help feeling that this was the sun of summer shining all the way back into winter\xe2\x80\x99s heart; just a glimpse to see how we were all doing here huddled together. That was enough to turn my thoughts to soil and seeds and new shoots rising.'b'THE average weekday New York Times contains nearly 130,000 words of news, information and opinion distilled from millions cascading in from throughout the world. The newspaper employs layers of editors and multiple policies and procedures to make sure that every one of those words is as accurate as anyone can determine in the daily rush of history.'b'But, with all the safeguards, bad things still happen. Last month, because reporters and editors in three different parts of the paper did not take enough pains to verify information, The Times reported as fact a political telephone call that didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen, fell victim to a faked letter to the editor, and published a sensational anecdote about a college football recruiting battle that the paper cannot be confident is true.'b'Each failure had its unique causes, but all show how little breakdowns can lead to big mistakes and how, in a business that relies heavily on trust, it is imperative to stay vigilant and skeptical.'b''b'The Phone Call'b''b'On Dec. 9, David Halbfinger, the metro politics reporter, 'b'wrote'b' that Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts had called Gov. David Paterson of New York on behalf of his niece, Caroline Kennedy, who was eyeing the Senate seat being vacated by Hillary Clinton. Halbfinger\xe2\x80\x99s sources were unnamed \xe2\x80\x9cDemocratic aides,\xe2\x80\x9d and the story said a Kennedy spokesman had no comment.'b'But the next day, after Paterson denied speaking to Kennedy and Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s spokesman said the senator had not called anyone in New York about his niece and the Senate, The Times 'b'acknowledged'b' that it had not contacted either Kennedy or Paterson to seek response before the article was published.'b'How could such a basic step have been missed? A chagrined Halbfinger took full responsibility and said there was \xe2\x80\x9cno rational explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d He said, \xe2\x80\x9cI had an out-of-mind experience for two hours, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t believe it happened. It was just awful.\xe2\x80\x9d The circumstances Halbfinger described amounted to a breakdown in communication with sources and fellow reporters.'b'He was the lead reporter on a story with three other contributors. Carl Hulse in Washington said he was asked to request an interview with Senator Kennedy but knew nothing about the reported phone call. He sent a message to Anthony Coley, Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s spokesman, asking if Kennedy would talk about \xe2\x80\x9cthe prospect of his niece joining him\xe2\x80\x9d in the Senate. Kennedy has not given press interviews since returning from surgery for brain cancer, and Coley signaled that there would be no interview this time. Halbfinger then sent his own message to Coley, referring to \xe2\x80\x9cthe Caroline thing,\xe2\x80\x9d and later asked Coley to call him. Coley replied that he would have \xe2\x80\x9cnothing for you on that story.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Halbfinger said he mistook the answer as a no-comment on the phone call. Instead, Coley was simply letting him know there would be no interview. Coley told me that had he been asked the direct question he would have waved The Times off. He said he thought the newspaper had made an \xe2\x80\x9chonest mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Halbfinger thought he had some corroboration because Nicholas Confessore, a reporter normally in the Albany bureau, was near him in the New York newsroom monitoring an interview on television with Kerry Kennedy, another niece of the senator\xe2\x80\x99s. Confessore announced that she had confirmed that her uncle had lobbied Paterson on Caroline\xe2\x80\x99s behalf, and he 'b'posted'b' that on the City Room blog. It turned out to be wrong.'b'Halbfinger said he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t explain why he didn\xe2\x80\x99t try to call Paterson. Also unexplained is whether the anonymous sources were in a position to know what they were talking about or had motives to mislead the paper. Craig Whitney, the standards editor, said the skimpy description of them was \xe2\x80\x9cinadequate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b' The Faked Letter'b''b'In his nine years as editor of letters to the editor, Thomas Feyer figures he has read a million letters \xe2\x80\x94 and spotted more than one fake. But on Dec. 18, he was taken in by an e-mail message from someone claiming to be Bertrand Delano\xc3\xab, the mayor of Paris, who said Caroline Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s bid for the Senate was \xe2\x80\x9ca dynastic move\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cnot very democratic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Feyer knew Delano\xc3\xab to be outspoken and not always diplomatic, so he didn\xe2\x80\x99t heed the little alarms that this might be a hoax: the e-mail address was 'b'paris.com'b' instead of paris.fr, and there were none of the required contact telephone numbers. Feyer also should have been suspicious because the message carried an ad at the bottom, unlikely with government communication. But he said the fact that the real mayor\xe2\x80\x99s name was in the originating address helped persuade him that the message was genuine. He has since learned how easy it is to create false e-mail addresses.'b'The 'b'letter'b' was lightly edited and sent back to the writer for approval, as required by Times policy. Although there was no response, the letter went in the paper on Dec. 22. When the real mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office objected, The Times 'b'apologized'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cThere were warning signs, \xe2\x80\x9c Feyer said. \xe2\x80\x9cI should have held the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He 'b'told readers'b' last Sunday that, from now on, The Times will adhere strictly to its verification policies for letters to the editor. All letter writers will be called before their submissions are published.'b'Andrew Rosenthal, the editor of the editorial page and Feyer\xe2\x80\x99s boss, said Feyer is \xe2\x80\x9cone of the most reliable, sensible editors I have ever known, with impeccable news judgment.\xe2\x80\x9d But he made \xe2\x80\x9cone real clunker,\xe2\x80\x9d Rosenthal added.'b'Feyer said he felt terrible about the incident because \xe2\x80\x9cthe credibility of The Times is everything.\xe2\x80\x9d He said he also felt a bit sad because \xe2\x80\x9cwe were operating with a level of trust that I suppose in today\xe2\x80\x99s Internet world you can\xe2\x80\x99t have.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'The Wild Party'b''b'On Dec. 26, Thayer Evans, a Houston-based freelancer who writes frequently for The Times, reported that one of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most intense college football recruiting battles had ended: Jamarkus McFarland of Lufkin, Tex., 'b'was going to Oklahoma'b', not Texas.'b'Evans had stayed close to McFarland and his mother, Kashemeyia Adams, for months, and he recounted an intense courtship of them by coaches and boosters. McFarland\xe2\x80\x99s paper described a party at an upscale Dallas hotel, hosted by Texas fans after the Texas-Oklahoma game, where he said drugs and alcohol were plentiful and young women took off their clothes and were \xe2\x80\x9cromancing each other.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But McFarland later 'b'told'b' rivals.com, a football fan Web site, that he had \xe2\x80\x9cspiced up\xe2\x80\x9d the description of the party and intimated that, if he had known Evans was going to quote from his paper, he could have told the reporter what was accurate and what was not. But he said that McFarland and his mother had never misled him during their long association.'b'Tom Jolly, the sports editor, and Mike Abrams, who was editing the 2,800-word article on deadline on Christmas Day, said they did not press Evans about the party. Nick Voinis, a spokesman for the University of Texas athletics department, complained to me that Evans did not call the university for comment before the article was published.'b'Evans did alert the university just before his article was published on the newspaper\xe2\x80\x99s Web site. Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t he seek reaction beforehand? He said that if anyone at Texas had spoken to him, it would have violated N.C.A.A. recruiting rules. And, he said, he did not want to give either Texas or Oklahoma information they could use to try to influence McFarland\xe2\x80\x99s decision.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI felt like we made the best efforts we could under the circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d Evans said.'b'Regardless of whether Texas officials would have commented, Evans should have given them the chance. As in each of the other cases, a phone call could have headed off much embarrassment.'b'Ronald Reagan may not have loved the press, but he had 'b'good advice'b' for every reporter: Trust but verify.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cWhere the Money Is,\xe2\x80\x9d by Bob Herbert (column, Jan. 13):'b'Mr. Herbert says the country should consider a financial transactions tax, an idea advocated by the economist Dean Baker. But I can speak for myself, as a white American who grew up in the segregated nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital of the 1960s. Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s day is one that I never thought would come, and one that I still can\xe2\x80\x99t quite believe is here.'b'Last week I joined a group of journalists at an off-the-record conversation with the president-elect, a sort of preview of the administration\xe2\x80\x99s coming attractions. But as I walked some desolate downtown blocks to the standard-issue federal office building serving as transition headquarters, ghosts of the past mingled with hopes for the future. The contrast between the unemployed men on Washington\xe2\x80\x99s frigid streets and the buzzing executive-branch bees inside was, for me, as old as time.'b'My particular historical vantage point is a product of my upbringing as that odd duck, a native Washingtonian whose parents were not in government. The first presidential transition of my sentient lifetime, Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s, I remember vividly. Even an 11-year-old could see that the sleepy Southern town of the Eisenhower era was waking up, electrified by youth, glamour and the prospect of change.'b'But some of that change I didn\xe2\x80\x99t then understand. J.F.K.\xe2\x80\x99s arrival coincided with Washington\xe2\x80\x99s emergence as the first American city 'b'with a black majority'b'. Many whites responded by fleeing to the suburbs. My parents did the opposite, moving our family from the enclave of Montgomery County, Md., into the city as I was about to enter the fifth grade.'b'Our new neighborhood included the Sidwell Friends School. My mother, a public school teacher, decreed that her children would instead enroll in the public system that had been desegregated a half-dozen years earlier, after Brown v. Board of Education. In reality de facto segregation remained in place. Though a few African-Americans and embassy Africans provided the window dressing of \xe2\x80\x9cintegration,\xe2\x80\x9d my mostly white elementary, junior high and high schools had roughly the same diversity as, say, today\xe2\x80\x99s G.O.P.'b'I wish I could say we were all outraged at this apartheid. But we were kids  \xe2\x80\x94  privileged kids at that  \xe2\x80\x94  and out of sight was out of mind. Except as household help, black Washington was generally as invisible to us as it was to the tourists who were rigidly segregated from the real Washington while visiting its many ivory marble shrines to democratic ideals.'b'Gradually we would learn more  \xe2\x80\x94  from our parents and teachers, from televised incidents of violent racial confrontations far away, and from odd cultural phenomena like the 1961 best seller \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Black Like Me'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d In that book, a white novelist darkened his skin  for undercover travels through deepest Dixie, whose bigotry he then described in morbid firsthand detail to shocked adolescents like me.'b'Surely such horrific injustices could not occur in our nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital.'b'But as an unintended consequence of Washington\xe2\x80\x99s particular brand of Jim Crow, white public school students got a tiny taste of what racially mandated second-class citizenship could mean. In those days, the city didn\xe2\x80\x99t even have the bastardized form of \xe2\x80\x9cself-government\xe2\x80\x9d it has now; it was run as a plantation by 'b'Congressional District panels'b' led by racist white Southerners (then Democrats). These overseers didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to lavish money on an overwhelmingly black school system, and they didn\xe2\x80\x99t. By the early 1960s, per-student spending in Washington was less than that of any state, impoverished West Virginia and Mississippi included.'b'If Washington\xe2\x80\x99s white schools received a larger share of that meager budget, as they no doubt did, it was still obvious that our teachers had far fewer resources than their suburban and private school counterparts. Extracurricular activities could be curtailed by the costs of light and heat. The curriculum was also abridged, lest anyone get too agitated by America\xe2\x80\x99s racial inequities. In my history class, the Civil War was downsized to a passing speed bump. In English, we read \xe2\x80\x9cTom Sawyer,\xe2\x80\x9d not \xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Now that we were teenagers, we had both the curiosity and mobility to investigate the strangely undemocratic city that dealt us this hand. In the words of Constance McLaughlin Green, a Pulitzer Prize-winning urban historian, the District\xe2\x80\x99s black population had long occupied \xe2\x80\x9ca secret city all but unknown to the white world round about.\xe2\x80\x9d We wanted in on the secrets.'b'There was so much we didn\xe2\x80\x99t know, so much Americans still don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Take the Lincoln Memorial, to which the Obama family paid so poignant a 'b'nocturnal visit'b' this month. If you look up coverage of the memorial\xe2\x80\x99s 1922 dedication ceremonies 'b'in The Times'b', you can read of President Harding\xe2\x80\x99s forceful oration commemorating the demise of slavery. You also learn that Dr. Robert R. Moton, the president of the Tuskegee Institute, was invited to pay tribute to Lincoln \xe2\x80\x9cin the name of 12,000,000 Negroes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s what The Times did not report about Moton: \xe2\x80\x9cInstead of being placed on the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s platform, he was relegated along with other distinguished colored people to an all-Negro section separated by a road from the rest of the audience.\xe2\x80\x9d So wrote Green in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Secret City,\xe2\x80\x9d her landmark history of race relations in Washington. This was no anomaly. A local Ku Klux Klan had been formed months earlier, with no protests from either Congress or the white press, and the young Harding administration had toughened the exclusion of blacks from the city\xe2\x80\x99s public recreation facilities.'b'The eye-opening \xe2\x80\x9cSecret City\xe2\x80\x9d recounting this secret history was not published until 1967, some four years after the Lincoln Memorial served as a backdrop for \xe2\x80\x9cI Have a Dream.\xe2\x80\x9d It was also in 1967 that I graduated from Woodrow Wilson High. As a valedictory, a bunch of us on the school paper voted to publish an editorial in favor of home rule for D.C. \xe2\x80\x9cWashingtonians have to beg, plead and cajole members of Congress for funds to renovate slums and slum schools,\xe2\x80\x9d it read. That was putting it mildly; we still had much to learn. But the editorial was enough of an irritant that our principal tried to censor it, which prompted a brief civic kerfuffle (\xe2\x80\x9cStudent Editorial Banned at Wilson\xe2\x80\x9d read the headline in The Washington Post) and jump-started a few starry-eyed careers in journalism and political activism.'b'It was one year later that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated and Washington\xe2\x80\x99s secret city exploded. The'b' fires and riots'b'came within a block of the building where the Obama transition set up shop.'b'One would like to say in the aftermath of the 2008 election that everyone lived happily ever after. But the American drama, especially when it involves race, is always more complicated than that.'b'Looking back at my high school years, I\xe2\x80\x99m struck by how slowly history can move. The great civil rights legislation of the Johnson administration had been accomplished 'b'in 1964'b' 'b'and 1965'b', but by the time of my graduation the impact was minimal \xe2\x80\x94  even in the city where the laws were written and passed. Today the nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital still has 'b'no voting representation'b' in Congress and is still a ward of the federal government, reduced to begging, pleading and cajoling for basic needs. Some 19 percent of the population 'b'lives below the poverty line'b', and that 19 percent remains a secret city to many who work within the Beltway.'b'Washington is its own special American case, but only up to a point. For all our huge progress, we are not \xe2\x80\x9cpost-racial,\xe2\x80\x9d whatever that means. The world doesn\xe2\x80\x99t change in a day, and the racial frictions that emerged in both the Democratic primary campaign and the general election didn\xe2\x80\x99t end on Nov. 4. As Obama himself said 'b'in his great speech on race'b', liberals couldn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cpurchase racial reconciliation on the cheap\xe2\x80\x9d simply by voting for him. And conservatives? The so-called party of Lincoln has spent much of the past month in spirited debate about whether a white candidate for the party\xe2\x80\x99s chairmanship did the right thing by 'b'sending out'b' a \xe2\x80\x9chumorous\xe2\x80\x9d recording of \xe2\x80\x9cBarack the Magic Negro\xe2\x80\x9d as a holiday gift.'b'Next to much of our history, this is small stuff. And yet: Of all the coverage of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s victory, the most accurate take may still be the piquant morning-after summation of the satirical newspaper  The Onion. Under the headline \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Man Given Nation\xe2\x80\x99s Worst Job,\xe2\x80\x9d it 'b'reported'b' that our new president will have \xe2\x80\x9cto spend four to eight years cleaning up the messes other people left behind.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Those messes are enormous, bigger than Washington, bigger than race, bigger than anything most of us have ever seen. Nearly three months after Election Day, it remains astonishing that the American people have entrusted the job to a young black man who seemed to come out of nowhere looking for that kind of work just as we most needed him.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn no other country on earth is my story even possible,\xe2\x80\x9d Obama is fond of saying. That is true, and that is what the country celebrates this week. But it is all the tragic American stories that came before him, some of them still playing out in chilly streets just blocks from the White House, that throw both his remarkable triumph and the huge challenge ahead of him into such heart-stopping relief.'b'A few years ago, soon after I returned disconsolate and shellshocked from a trip to Darfur, I found New Yorkers burning with moral outrage.'b'The spark wasn\xe2\x80\x99t genocide, war or poverty, but rather homelessness \xe2\x80\x94 of a red-tailed hawk nicknamed Pale Male. Managers of a Fifth Avenue apartment building had dismantled his nest.'b'Fury! Television cameras! And public pressure that led to a solution for rebuilding the nest.'b'I wondered how some of that compassion for a hawk could be rechanneled to help human beings like those I had just seen dying in Darfur. The potential is vast: just imagine if we felt the same sympathy for the 25,000 children who will die today of poverty as we do for, say, a lost and terrified puppy on the street. But it\xe2\x80\x99s very difficult to generate activism for distant people whom we can\xe2\x80\x99t visualize.'b'So I concocted a contest to take a university student with me on a reporting trip to Africa. I figured that the student\xe2\x80\x99s journey might help connect American students to truly desperate needs abroad.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve held two of these student trips so far, and today I\xe2\x80\x99m delighted to announce the third.'b'If you apply, you should know that within The Times, my colleagues say that first prize is one trip with Kristof. Second prize is two trips.'b'But they\xe2\x80\x99re just jealous. The trip may not be comfortable, but if you don\xe2\x80\x99t obsess about rats under the beds, bats in the outhouses or drunken soldiers at checkpoints, then the trip will be memorable and perhaps even life-changing.'b'If you win, you won\xe2\x80\x99t be practicing tourism but journalism. You\xe2\x80\x99ll blog for 'b'nytimes.com'b' and file videos for The Times and for 'b'YouTube'b'.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m doing this for two reasons. First, I want to engage young people about global issues that I\xe2\x80\x99m passionate about. Second, it\xe2\x80\x99s good journalism, for you\xe2\x80\x99ll bring a tool to reporting from Africa that I no longer have: a fresh eye.'b'The contest is open to undergraduate or graduate students at American universities. Details for applying are on my blog, 'b'www.nytimes.com/ontheground'b'. You can apply by essay or by video on YouTube, or both. The International Committee of the Red Cross will help me winnow the applicant pool, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll pick the winner.'b'For my first win-a-trip journey, I chose a Mississippi student, 'b'Casey Parks'b', who had never been out of the country. In rural Cameroon, we came across 'b'Prudence Lemokouno'b', a mother of three who was dying in childbirth. We gave money and donated blood in hopes of saving Prudence. We failed, and we watched Prudence\xe2\x80\x99s life ebb away.'b'Casey and I visited the Central African Republic and played basketball in a forest clearing \xe2\x80\x94 against Pygmies. Then we traveled to insecure areas to understand the human toll of banditry. Our reporting went well: we were held up at gunpoint. Twice.'b'The 'b'second trip'b', with Leana Wen, a medical student, and 'b'Will Okun'b', a Chicago teacher, started with a tour of booming Rwanda. Then in Congo we dined with a warlord in the jungle \xe2\x80\x94 and interviewed villagers raped by his troops.'b'A documentary of that second trip, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Reporter'b',\xe2\x80\x9d premiered at the Sundance Film Festival on Friday and will be shown on HBO later this year.'b'In this brutal economic environment, it\xe2\x80\x99s especially difficult to sustain compassion for people out of our line of sight. But the contest winner can help put a face on global poverty \xe2\x80\x94 the child who contracts malaria for want of a $5 bed net.'b'Grass-roots reporting encourages not only compassion but also a tough-minded appreciation for the messiness of life and the complexity of solutions. In many cases, the family is too poor to buy a bed net not just because of poverty but also because Dad spends the family money on his priority, which is banana beer.'b'One of the failures of the American education system is that it rarely exposes students to life around the world. As Bill Gates put it in his 2007 Harvard commencement address, \xe2\x80\x9cI left Harvard with no real awareness of the awful inequities in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s hope that Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s presidency makes public service more appealing. But if you want to save the world, you first must understand it.'b'So, embed yourself deep within a developing country for a summer or a year. I wish colleges would offer credit for such gritty experiences \xe2\x80\x94 and extra credit for getting intestinal worms.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve posted some overseas volunteer possibilities, from helping at a maternity hospital in Somaliland to teaching English to brothel children in India, on my blog. Even if you don\xe2\x80\x99t win my trip, you can still win your own.'b'I was walking by a TV the other day and CNN was on, airing a hearing of what seemed to be a banking committee in Congress debating whether to release more bailout money. CNN didn\xe2\x80\x99t identify the lawmaker who was speaking. He had a bit of a Southern drawl. But I burst out laughing when he said something like: \xe2\x80\x9cI remember a time when banks lent money to people. Now it\xe2\x80\x99s the other way around.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yes, kids, those were the days  \xe2\x80\x94  when banks lent money to the people not the people to the banks!'b'Many commentators have suggestions for Barack Obama on what should be his first meeting at the White House. Here is mine: Mr. Obama and his economic team should convene the 300 leading bank presidents in the East Room and the president should say to each one of them something like this:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLadies and gentlemen, this crisis started with you, the bankers, engaging in reckless practices, and it will only end when we clean up your mess and start afresh. The banking system is the heart of our economy. It pumps blood to our industrial muscles, and right now it\xe2\x80\x99s not pumping. We all know that in the past six months you\xe2\x80\x99ve gone from one extreme to another. You\xe2\x80\x99ve gone from lending money to anyone who could fog up a knife to now treating all potential borrowers, no matter how healthy, as bankrupt until proven innocent. And, therefore, you\xe2\x80\x99re either not lending to them or lending under such onerous terms that the economy can\xe2\x80\x99t get any liftoff. No amount of stimulus will work without a healthy banking system.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo here\xe2\x80\x99s what we\xe2\x80\x99re going to do: we\xe2\x80\x99re going to unclog the arteries. My banking experts have analyzed each of your balance sheets. You will tell us if we\xe2\x80\x99re right. Those of you who are insolvent, we will nationalize and shut down. We will auction off your viable assets and will hold the toxic ones in a government reconstruction fund and sell them later when the market rebounds. Those of you who are weak will be merged. And those of you who are strong will receive added capital for your balance sheets, after you write down all your remaining toxic waste. I am not going to continue rewarding the losers and dimwits amongst you with handouts.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Without this sort of come-to-Jesus strategy, we\xe2\x80\x99re going to continue to just limp along. We\xe2\x80\x99ll never quite confront the real problem because we don\xe2\x80\x99t want to take the upfront pain. Therefore, the market will never clear  \xe2\x80\x94  meaning start-ups in need of capital will be choked in their cribs and profit-making firms won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to grow as they should.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRight now,\xe2\x80\x9d said David Smick, author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe World Is Curved,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthe bankers are sitting on mountains of cash, including our bailout money, because they know their true balance sheets are a disaster  \xe2\x80\x94  far worse than publicly stated.\xe2\x80\x9d The situation will likely worsen as delinquent consumer and auto loans are piled atop bad mortgages. \xe2\x80\x9cObama needs to inject some truth serum into the banking discussion. No one trusts the banks, and even the bankers don\xe2\x80\x99t trust each other.\xe2\x80\x9d Bringing clarity to bank balance sheets, said Smick, \xe2\x80\x9cis the first step to fixing America\xe2\x80\x99s bank lending problem.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Only after we bring full transparency to the bank balance sheets will we see private capital buying into banks again at scale. But have no illusions. There are still real balance sheet problems that have to be surmounted. This is not just a psychological crisis.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI wish people would stop saying that this is a crisis of confidence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Steven Eisman, a portfolio manager and banking expert at FrontPoint Partners. \xe2\x80\x9cThe loss of confidence is just a symptom of bad credit and over-leverage. The banks are not lending because they know their balance sheets are loaded with future losses and they don\xe2\x80\x99t have enough capital. The TARP gave them preferred equity, which is nothing more than a bridge loan. We need the government to force the banks to write down all their bad assets now and then recapitalize themselves, preferably with private capital. Those banks that cannot raise sufficient capital should be seized and their deposits sold off.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For too long the government has been taking the banks at their own words, which is one reason we keep getting surprised with demands for more bailout cash. The Treasury needs to be doing its own brutal, burn-down analysis of every major bank\xe2\x80\x99s balance sheet  \xe2\x80\x94  and then acting accordingly.'b'In recent years, \xe2\x80\x9cwhenever other countries  \xe2\x80\x94  Russia, Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea or Mexico  \xe2\x80\x94  got themselves into an economic crisis, we lectured them about how they had to adopt \xe2\x80\x98shock therapy,\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d said Mois\xc3\xa9s Na\xc3\xadm, editor of Foreign Policy magazine. \xe2\x80\x9cBut now that we are the ones in crisis and in need of shock therapy, everyone is preaching gradualism.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A stimulus package that does not also unclog the arteries of our banking system will never stimulate sufficiently. Mr. Obama should take the pain early, blame it all on George Bush and then reap the benefits down the road. Postpone the pain, postpone the recovery.'b'WASHINGTON'b'As Barack Obama got to town, one of the first things he did was seek the counsel of past presidents, including George Bush senior.'b'As W. was leaving town, one of the last things he did was explain why he never sought the counsel of his father on issues that his father knew intimately, like Iraq and Saddam.'b'When Brit Hume did a joint interview last week with Bush father and son, dubbed \xe2\x80\x9c41st guy\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c43rd guy\xe2\x80\x9d by W., the Fox anchor asked whether it was true that \xe2\x80\x9cthere wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a lot of give and take\xe2\x80\x9d between them, except on family matters.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSee,\xe2\x80\x9d the Oedipally oddball W. replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthe interesting thing is that a president has got plenty of advisers, but what a president never has is someone who gave him unconditional love.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He talks about his father, the commander in chief who went to war with Saddam before he did, like a puppy. \xe2\x80\x9cYou rarely have people,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwho can pick up the phone and say, \xe2\x80\x98I love you, son,\xe2\x80\x99 or, \xe2\x80\x98Hang in there, son.\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Maybe he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have needed so many Hang-in-there-sons if he had actually consulted his dad before he ignorantly and fraudulently rammed into the Middle East.'b'When W. admits the convoluted nature of his relationship with his father, diminishing a knowledgeable former president to the status of a blankie, you realize that, despite all the cocky swagger we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen,  this is not a confident man.'b'That is vividly apparent as we watch W. and Obama share the stage as they pass the battered baton. One seems small and inconsequential, even though he keeps insisting he\xe2\x80\x99s not; the other grows large and impressive, filling Americans with cockeyed hope even as he warns them not to expect too much too soon.'b'Even Obama\xe2\x80\x99s caution \xe2\x80\x94 a commodity notably absent from the White House for eight years \xe2\x80\x94 fills people with optimism.'b'W. lives in the shadow of his father\xe2\x80\x99s presence, while Obama lives in the shadow of his father\xe2\x80\x99s absence. W.\xe2\x80\x99s parlous presidency, spent trashing the Constitution, the economy and the environment, was bound up, and burdened by, the psychological traits of an asphyxiated and pampered son.'b'The exiting and entering presidents are opposite poles \xe2\x80\x94  one the parody of a monosyllabic Western gunslinger who disdains nuance, and one a complex, polysyllabic professor sort who will make a decision only after he has held it up to the light and examined it from all sides.'b'W. was immune to doubt and afraid of it. (His fear of doubt led to the cooking of war intelligence.) Obama is delighted by doubt.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s astonishing that, as banks continue to fail and Americans continue to lose jobs and homes, W. was obtuse enough to go on TV and give a canned ode to can-do-ism. \xe2\x80\x9cGood and evil are present in this world,\xe2\x80\x9d he reiterated, \xe2\x80\x9cand between the two of them there can be no compromise.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He gives the good-and-evil view of things a bad name. Good and evil are not like the Redskins and the Cowboys. Good and evil intermingle in the same breath, let alone the same society. A moral analysis cannot be a simplistic analysis.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou may not agree with some of the tough decisions I have made,\xe2\x80\x9d he said Thursday night. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I hope you can agree that I was willing to make the tough decisions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Actually, no. His decisions have been, for the most part, disastrous. If he\xe2\x80\x99d paid as much attention to facts as fitness, 9/11, Iraq, the drowning of New Orleans, the deterioration in Afghanistan and the financial deregulation orgy could have been prevented.'b'Bush fancied himself the Decider; Obama fancies himself the Convener. It feels good.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cWhere Sweatshops Are a Dream\xe2\x80\x9d (column, Jan. 15):'b'Nicholas D. Kristof is absolutely right. Sweatshops are much better than a sharp stick in the eye. Behson'b'\nNyack, N.Y., Jan. 13, 2009'b''b''b'The writer is an associate professor of management at the Silberman College of Business, Fairleigh Dickinson University.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'The adoption by M.I.T. and other universities of better ways of teaching physics could have a broad impact on science teaching in high schools.'b'Many, perhaps most, of those who become high school and middle school science teachers did not find it difficult to learn physics or chemistry or biology through the old methods and, consciously or unconsciously, seek to emulate their own science teachers. This means they rely on some version of the lecture; students find out in class what they have to learn and go home and try to learn it on their own.'b'Better science teaching in universities may lead to better science teaching in secondary schools, a higher level of scientific literacy and better performance of American students on international tests. 'b''b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cIsraelis United on Gaza War Even as Censure Rises Abroad\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 13):'b'I have a question for those here and in Israel who support the Gaza war. Or will it continue down the road of becoming an international pariah?'b'Susan Hussein'b'\nBoonton, N.J., Jan. 13, 2009'b''b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cPurple Heart Is Ruled Out for Traumatic Stress\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 8):'b'The decision by the Pentagon to deny Purple Hearts to veterans with psychic wounds flies in the face of the many public statements from the Defense Department about the need to reduce the stigma associated with these injuries.'b'It is disturbing that the Pentagon needs to see blood to establish the validity of a war injury.'b'Those of us who treat our war veterans have no doubt that \xe2\x80\x9chidden\xe2\x80\x9d psychic injuries are at least as serious and potentially more devastating than more visible physical ones.'b'Ask any veteran or family member of someone suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder, traumatic brain injury or post-deployment depression about the reality of these wounds. They will have no trouble describing the profound consequences of these injuries and their far-reaching effects on families and communities.'b'The sacrifice and suffering of these veterans need to be recognized and honored.'b'Judith Broder'b'\n Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 9, 2009'b''b''b'The writer, a medical doctor, is the founder and director of the Soldiers Project in Los Angeles, which offers free psychological treatment to military service members who have served or expect to serve in Iraq or Afghanistan.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cPTSD and the Purple Heart\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 12):'b'Post-traumatic stress disorder is one of the signature wounds of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, yet our government remains painfully slow to recognize PTSD as an injury of war.'b'The ways in which mental wounds affect a soldier\xe2\x80\x99s daily life may be less visible than physical wounds, but the impact can be just as severe. PTSD is frequently misdiagnosed, and benefits for the condition are often denied by the Veterans Administration.'b'Whatever one\xe2\x80\x99s position on PTSD as a qualifying injury for the Purple Heart, the debate illustrates a deeper injustice throughout the Pentagon and V.A. \xe2\x80\x94 the lack of parity between physical and mental injuries from military service.'b'Last year Congress passed a law giving Americans the right to receive equal coverage from private insurance companies for mental and physical health care. John J. Hall 'b'\n Washington, Jan. 13, 2009'b''b''b'The writer is chairman of the House Veterans\xe2\x80\x99 Affairs Subcommittee on Disability Assistance and Memorial Affairs.'b''b'UNTIL a martyred John F. Kennedy replaced him, Abraham Lincoln was one of the two white men whose image most frequently graced even the most modest black home, second in popularity only to Jesus. Perhaps none of his heirs in the Oval Office has been as directly compared to Lincoln as will Barack Obama, in part because Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s Emancipation Proclamation began freeing the slaves descended from the continent on which Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s father was born, and in part because of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s own fascination with Lincoln himself.'b'Much has been written about what Mr. Obama thinks about Lincoln; but not much has been said about what Lincoln would think of Barack Hussein Obama. If his marble statue at the Lincoln Memorial could become flesh and speak, like Galatea,  what would the man who is remembered for freeing the slaves say about his first black successor?'b'It is difficult to say for sure, of course, but one thing we can be fairly certain about is that Lincoln would have been, um, surprised. Lincoln was thoroughly a man of his times, and while he staunchly opposed slavery \xe2\x80\x94 on moral grounds and because it  made competition in the marketplace unfair for poor white men \xe2\x80\x94 for most of his life he harbored fixed and unfortunate ideas about race.'b'Lincoln had a very complex relationship with blacks. Abolition was a fundamental part of Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s moral compass, but equality was not. While he was an early, consistent and formidable foe of slavery, Lincoln had much more ambivalent feelings about blacks themselves, especially about whether they were, or could ever be, truly equal with whites.'b'For example, on Aug. 14, 1862, he invited five black men to the White House to convince them to become the founders of a new nation in Panama consisting of those slaves he was about to free. A month before emancipation became law, he proposed a constitutional amendment guaranteeing financing for blacks who wished to emigrate to Liberia or Haiti.'b'Degrading words, deplored by most white abolitionists, like \xe2\x80\x9cSambo\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCuffee,\xe2\x80\x9d found their way into Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s descriptions of blacks; he even used \xe2\x80\x9cnigger\xe2\x80\x9d several times in speeches. He also liked to tell \xe2\x80\x9cdarkie\xe2\x80\x9d jokes and had a penchant for black-faced minstrel shows. The Lincoln of pre-White House days was a long way from the Great Emancipator; \xe2\x80\x9crecovering racist\xe2\x80\x9d would be closer to the truth.'b'Except for his barber, William Florville,  and William Johnson, a servant from Springfield, Ill., Lincoln didn\xe2\x80\x99t know many of what he referred to as \xe2\x80\x9cvery intelligent\xe2\x80\x9d black people before he moved to the White House. (In 1840, only 116 blacks lived in Springfield, and they were domestics, laborers or slaves.) In fact, if we add up the amount of time he spent with black people who were not servants even after he became president, it probably would not amount to 24 hours.'b'The truth is that successful blacks were almost total strangers to Lincoln, born as he was on the frontier and raised in a state settled by white Southerners. From this perspective, then, Lincoln most probably would have been shocked, perhaps horrified, by Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s election. Like the majority of Northern whites, Lincoln had a vision of America that was largely a white one.'b'Once in office, though, he met with more black leaders than any president before him, including Sojourner Truth (whom he unfortunately addressed as \xe2\x80\x9cAunty\xe2\x80\x9d), Henry Highland Garnet and Martin R. Delany, even if he never invited one to a formal meal. But we also know that Lincoln could recognize exceptional people, regardless of race.'b'As president, he became quite taken with one black man, Frederick Douglass, who initially seems to bear much in common with Barack Obama. Both Mr. Obama and Douglass had one black and one white parent; both rose from humble origins to become famous before age 45; both are among the greatest writers and orators of their generations; and both learned early to use words as powerful weapons. Lincoln, seeing this masterly orator of mixed-race ancestry, would most likely first have been reminded of his exceptional friend, Douglass.'b'Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s respect for Douglass \xe2\x80\x94 the first, and perhaps only, black man he treated as an intellectual equal \xe2\x80\x94 was total. He met with him at the White House three times and once told a colleague that he considered Douglass among the nation\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cmost meritorious men.\xe2\x80\x9d And just after delivering his second inaugural address, Lincoln asked Douglass  what he thought of the speech, adding that \xe2\x80\x9cthere is no man in the country whose opinion I value more than yours.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The fact that Lincoln was no natural friend of the Negroes arguably makes his actions on their behalf all the more impressive, even if they were motivated by the urgent pragmatism of war. He and Douglass were unlikely allies: Douglass was a firebrand in the prophetic tradition, whereas Lincoln \xe2\x80\x94 like Barack Obama \xe2\x80\x94 spoke of pragmatism and post-partisanship. While Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s election may mark the triumph of Douglass\xe2\x80\x99s grand historical project for American race relations, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mark the ascent of another Douglass.'b'Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s great achievement, in the eyes of posterity, was really the outcome of his ingrained pragmatism. The Emancipation Proclamation was born of a certain opportunism (to win the war, Lincoln said, he needed freed slaves to defeat their former masters), and is not a lesser thing for it. Perhaps there is a lesson for Mr. Obama here: those who invoke high ideas and scorn compromise often bring themselves into disrepute. Those whose actions are conditioned by an exquisite sense of frailty, by an understanding that it\xe2\x80\x99s more important to avoid the worst than to attain the best, may better serve those ideals in the end.'b'Is Barack Obama another Abraham Lincoln? Let\xe2\x80\x99s hope not. Greatness \xe2\x80\x94 witness the presidencies of Lincoln, say, and Franklin D. Roosevelt \xe2\x80\x94 is forged in the crucible of disaster. It comes when character is equal to cataclysm. A peacetime Lincoln would have been no Lincoln at all. Let\xe2\x80\x99s hope that Mr. Obama, for all of his considerable gifts, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t get this particular chance to be great.'b'Barack Obama has written that Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9chumble beginnings ... often speak to our own.\xe2\x80\x9d Once Lincoln had recovered from his shock that a descendant of \xe2\x80\x9camalgamation\xe2\x80\x9d (about which he once expressed reservations) had ascended to the presidency, one suspects their mutual embrace of economic independence and natural rights, their love and mastery of the English language, their shared desire to leave their mark on history, and their astonishing gift for pragmatic improvisation, would have drawn him to a man so fundamentally similar to himself.'b'FORTY-ONE years ago, I was blessed to spend the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\xe2\x80\x99s last birthday with him, along with Allard Lowenstein and staff members like Andy Young, Hosea Williams, Dorothy Cotton, James Bevel, James Orange and others. I recall vividly how he spent that day \xe2\x80\x94 and I mention it now because it\xe2\x80\x99s instructive to all of us if we are to follow Dr. King\xe2\x80\x99s example and not just admire him.'b'When Barack Obama is sworn in as the nation\xe2\x80\x99s first African-American president, many will view that moment as the culmination of the modern civil rights movement, a struggle most often identified with Dr. King.'b'It is fitting that Mr. Obama will assume the nation\xe2\x80\x99s highest office one day after we celebrate Dr. King\xe2\x80\x99s birthday. What would Dr. King, who spent much of his life changing conditions so that African-Americans could vote without fear of death or intimidation, think of the rise of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s 44th president?'b'I can say without reservation that he would be beaming. I am equally confident that he would not let the euphoria of the moment blind us to the unfinished business that lies ahead. And he would spell out those challenges in biblical terms: feed the hungry, clothe the naked and study war no more.'b'Dr. King spent his 39th birthday working. I remember him coming to the basement of Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta. He walked in that day around 9 a.m., after breakfast with his family, wearing blue jeans and a windbreaker. (I recall a bright, sunny day.) He convened the Southern Christian Leadership Conference staff and a rainbow coalition \xe2\x80\x94 blacks from the Deep South, whites from Appalachia, Jewish allies from New York, Latino farm worker organizers \xe2\x80\x94 to plan what would be his last campaign, the Poor People\xe2\x80\x99s March to the nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital. Though Dr. King had met with increasing hostility from the press and government, his mood was upbeat because we were energized by the vision of a new initiative to advance our movement.'b'Around noon Xernona Clayton, a friend of the King family, walked in with a birthday cake. She teased Dr. King, saying that he was \xe2\x80\x9cso busy you forgot to celebrate your own birthday.\xe2\x80\x9d Slightly embarrassed, Dr. King blew out the candles. We must have eaten the cake in record time because it seemed that within moments the plates were cleared and we were back in our meeting \xe2\x80\x94 with Al Lowenstein conducting a workshop about the march and how to step up pressure to end the Vietnam War.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the model we should follow this week \xe2\x80\x94 and beyond. We should celebrate the election of our new president. And then we should get back to work to complete the unfinished business of making America a more perfect union.'b'With apologies to Billy Joel, who\xe2\x80\x99s more of a chronologist, and in tribute to a president, Barack Hussein Obama, representing a new post-cold-war generation of 21st-century Americans.'b''b'We Didn\xe2\x80\x99t Start the Fire (2)'b''b''b'Bill Clinton, Tina Fey, capitalist China, O.J.,\n'b' Asia rising, Facebook, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar\n'b''b' Dick Cheney, Rumsfeld, Ugg boots, Seinfeld\n'b' West Bank, Gaza City, Tupac Amaru Shakur\n'b''b'Mohamed Atta, W.M.D., Harry Potter, Reality TV\n'b' Tom Cruise, American Beauty, MP3, Oprah Winfrey\n'b''b'Schwarzenegger, YouTube, America\xe2\x80\x99s got organic food\n'b' Armstrong, blogosphere, Monica Lewinsky\n'b''b''b' We didn\xe2\x80\x99t start the fire'b'\n'b''b' It was always burning'b'\n'b''b' Since the world\xe2\x80\x99s been turning'b'\n'b''b' We didn\xe2\x80\x99t start the fire'b'\n'b''b' No we didn\xe2\x80\x99t light it'b'\n'b''b' But we tried to fight it'b'\n'b''b'Vlad Putin, Medvedev, Assad, Posh-and-Becks\n'b' The West Wing, Y2K, massacre in Falluja\n'b''b'Britney Spears, Spike Lee, Kurt Cobain, Sarkozy\n'b' Mia Hamm, Heath Ledger, Viagra, Napster\n'b''b'Lindsay Lohan, skinny jeans, Boston\xe2\x80\x99s got a winning team\n'b' Lehman Brothers, A.I.G., subprime, Ponzi scheme\n'b''b'Rwanda, Darfur, Bosnia, and a billion poor,\n'b' Tehran, Hezbollah, trouble with the jihadis\n'b''b''b' We didn\xe2\x80\x99t start the fire'b'\n'b''b' It was always burning'b'\n'b''b' Since the world\xe2\x80\x99s been turning'b'\n'b''b' We didn\xe2\x80\x99t start the fire'b'\n'b''b' No we didn\xe2\x80\x99t light it'b'\n'b''b' But we tried to fight it'b'\n'b''b' New Orleans, Bola\xc3\xb1o, Sarah Palin no-go\n'b' TiVo, Hu Jintao, and the vegan-eco crowd\n'b''b'Tony Blair, Paris Hilton, Princess Di, Bin Laden\n'b' Pyongyang, the renditions gang, Roger Clemens in a cloud\n'b''b'ACT UP, Infinite Jest, O.J.
