synagogue on Saturday, before saying the customary prayer for our country, the rabbi asked us to reflect on the fact that a new president would be inaugurated on Tuesday, and urged us to focus a little more intently than usual on the prayer. The congregants did so, it seemed to me, as we read, \xe2\x80\x9cOur God and God of our ancestors: We ask your blessings for our country \xe2\x80\x94 for its government, for its leaders and advisers, and for all who exercise just and rightful authority ...\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Barack Obama will assume that just and rightful authority at noon on Tuesday. After a dinner with him that I attended last week, as we said our goodbyes, I overheard one of my fellow conservatives say softly to the president-elect, \xe2\x80\x9cSir, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be praying for you.\xe2\x80\x9d Obama seemed to pause as they shook hands, and to thank him more earnestly than he did those of us who simply \xe2\x80\x94 and sincerely \xe2\x80\x94 wished him well.'b'The incoming president is the man of the moment. He deserves good wishes and sincere prayers. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve found myself thinking these last few days more about the man who has shouldered the burdens of office for the past eight years, George W. Bush.'b'He wasn\xe2\x80\x99t my favorite among Republicans in 2000. He has made mistakes as president, and has limitations as a leader. But he has exercised his just and rightful authority in a way \xe2\x80\x94 I believe \xe2\x80\x94 that deserves recognition and respect.'b'It will probably be a while before he gets much of either. In synagogue, right after the prayer for our country, there is a prayer for the state of Israel, asking the \xe2\x80\x9crock and redeemer of the people Israel\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cspread over it the shelter of your peace.\xe2\x80\x9d As we recited this on Saturday, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help but reflect that a distressingly small number of my fellow Jews seem to have given much thought at all to the fact that President Bush is one of the greatest friends the state of Israel \xe2\x80\x94 and, yes, the Jewish people \xe2\x80\x94 have had in quite a while. Bush stood with Israel when he had no political incentive to do so and received no political benefit from doing so. He was criticized by much of the world. He did it because he thought it the right thing to do.'b'He has been denounced for this, as Israel has been denounced for doing what it judged necessary to defend itself. The liberal sage Bill Moyers has been a harsh critic of Bush. On Jan. 9, on PBS, he also lambasted Israel for what he called its \xe2\x80\x9cstate terrorism,\xe2\x80\x9d its \xe2\x80\x9cwaging war on an entire population\xe2\x80\x9d in Gaza. He traced this Israeli policy back to the Bible, where \xe2\x80\x9cGod-soaked violence became genetically coded,\xe2\x80\x9d apparently in both Arabs and Jews. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t presume to say what is and isn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cgenetically coded\xe2\x80\x9d in Moyers\xe2\x80\x99s respectable Protestant genes. But I\xe2\x80\x99m glad it was George W. Bush calling the shots over the last eight years, not someone well-thought of by Moyers.'b'Many of Bush\xe2\x80\x99s defenders have praised him for keeping the country safe since Sept. 11, 2001. He deserves that praise, and I\xe2\x80\x99m perfectly happy to defend most of his surveillance, interrogation and counterterrorism policies against his critics.'b'But I don\xe2\x80\x99t think keeping us safe has been Bush\xe2\x80\x99s most impressive achievement. That was winning the war in Iraq, and in particular, his refusal to accept defeat when so many counseled him to do so in late 2006. His ordering the surge of troops to Iraq in January 2007 was an act of personal courage and of presidential leadership. The results have benefited both Iraq and the United States. And the outcome in Iraq is a remarkable gift to the incoming president, who now only has to sustain success, rather than trying to deal with the consequences in the region and around the world of a humiliating withdrawal and a devastating defeat.'b'The cost of the war in Iraq, and in Afghanistan, has been great. Last Wednesday afternoon, in the midst of all the other activities of the final week of an administration, Bush had 40 or so families of fallen soldiers to the White House. The staff had set aside up to two hours. Bush, a man who normally keeps to schedule, spent over four hours meeting in small groups with the family members of those who had fallen in battle.'b'This past weekend Barack Obama added to his itinerary a visit to Arlington National Cemetery. Obama knows that he, too, will be a war president. He knows the decisions he makes as commander in chief will be his most consequential. And so on Sunday morning, before going to church, he placed a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns and stood silently as taps was sounded. The somber tableau provided quite a contrast to all the hubbub and talk of the last few days. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s silent tribute captured a deeper truth, and \xe2\x80\x94 I dare say \xe2\x80\x94 a more fundamental hope, than could any speech.'b'From plug-in cars to carbon capture to wind farms linked to \xe2\x80\x9cintelligent\xe2\x80\x9d power grids, many of the solutions pitched to restructure the country\xe2\x80\x99s energy system and confront global warming rely on a faith in high tech: we expect, or at least hope, that an Apollo project, the energy equivalent of the 'b'dot.com'b' revolution or some other burst of creative genius will engineer the problem away.'b'Obviously, game-changing technologies will play a big role in cutting America\xe2\x80\x99s consumption of fossil fuels. They will also be essential to achieving the reductions in greenhouse gas emissions that most scientists think will be necessary to avoid the worst consequences of climate change. But as it frames its strategy to deal with both problems, the Obama administration cannot overlook the low-hanging fruit \xe2\x80\x94 the gains to be had from making existing technologies more efficient.'b'The plain truth is that the United States is an inefficient user of energy. For each dollar of economic product, the United States spews more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than 93 of 137 countries tracked in the indicators of the International Energy Agency. Those doing better include not only cutting-edge nations like Japan but low-tech countries like Thailand and Mexico.'b'True, energy efficiency has improved, especially in states like California. But American drivers, households and businesses still use more energy than those in most other rich countries to do the same thing. The United States spends more energy to produce a ton of cement clinker than Canada, Mexico and even China. It is one of the most energy-intensive makers of pulp and paper, emitting more than three times as much carbon dioxide per ton as Brazil and twice as much as South Korea.'b'Per-capita carbon dioxide emissions by households in the United States and Canada are the highest in the world \xe2\x80\x94 in part because of bigger homes. And the energy efficiency of electricity production from fossil fuels is lower in the United States than in most rich countries and some poor ones, mainly because of the higher share of coal in the mix.'b'Transportation tells the same story. The United States uses the most energy per passenger mile among the 18 rich economies surveyed by the energy agency. In 2006, the American auto fleet used, on average, a little less than five gallons of gas to travel 100 miles. The Irish went the same distance with under four gallons, the Italians with less than three, basically because they use smaller cars that get better mileage.'b'The Union of Concerned Scientists points out that switching from an S.U.V. that gets 14 miles per gallon to one that gets 16 would save the same amount of fuel as swapping a 35-mile-a-gallon car for a 51-m.p.g. new generation gas-sipper. This is not an argument for more S.U.V.\xe2\x80\x99s. It simply shows that we can wring savings from modest efficiency gains in products we already use.'b'A study by McKinsey &amp; Company last year argued that most of the carbon abatement needed between now and 2030 could be achieved with existing technologies, things like insulating homes, improving fuel efficiency, and switching to concentrated laundry detergents to reduce packaging and transport costs. Merely improving transmissions would vastly increase fuel economy.'b'A quantum jump in energy efficiency will still require political leadership. Cheap energy has kept America from making the necessary investments. Yet they must be made; neither the country nor the atmosphere can wait for high tech to ride to the rescue.'b'The United Arab Emirates has bested other oil-rich Persian Gulf countries by becoming the first to conclude a legally binding nuclear cooperation agreement with the Bush administration. It deserves even greater congratulations for forswearing uranium enrichment and plutonium reprocessing. Those are the key processes for making fuel for nuclear reactors \xe2\x80\x94 or nuclear weapons.'b'Many countries have these agreements \xe2\x80\x94 known in the business as 123\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x94 with Washington, which allow them to buy American nuclear reactors and fuel. But none have made that important concession.'b'Under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, all members in good standing have the right to make their own fuel. But the temptations are considerable and the technology far too easy to divert (see Iran).'b'That is why the U.A.E\xe2\x80\x99s choice is so especially important, and why other nuclear suppliers should be encouraging their clients to make the same choice.'b'Nuclear energy is one way to address climate change, and developing countries \xe2\x80\x94 that agree to international rules for inspections \xe2\x80\x94 must have the same access to nuclear technology as the developed world.'b'President Bush promoted nuclear energy with gusto but notably failed to develop a strategy to ensure that a proliferation of nuclear power would not also lead to a proliferation of nuclear weapons. Mr. Obama and the new Congress must do better.'b'More than 25 nations plan to build nuclear power plants for the first time. That includes Saudi Arabia, which is negotiating its own cooperation deal with Washington.'b'Many of these countries say they must diversify to meet future energy needs. And the major nuclear suppliers are only too eager to compete for their business.'b'Too often these countries ignore serious questions about whether more nuclear plants will pose new safety and waste disposal hazards, and whether their clients\xe2\x80\x99 sudden enthusiasm is driven less by concerns about global warming or declining oil reserves and more by rising fears of Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear ambitions and appetites for their own weapons programs.'b'Congress must review the U.A.E. deal before it is finalized. Some lawmakers have raised worrisome questions about goods with military or potential nuclear- related uses moving through Dubai, one of the emirates, to Iran. Officials there must explain how they plan to strengthen their export controls. If not, Congress may have to slow its approval or place tougher restrictions on the 123 agreement until it is sure that American technology sold to the U.A.E. cannot be diverted.'b'There is also something unsettling about the slick lobbying campaign the U.A.E. has mounted to push the deal through quickly.'b'The agreement sets an important and welcome new standard. But Congress must exercise due diligence with this agreement and all of the others that will follow.'b'Lasantha Wickramatunga, an extraordinarily courageous journalist, wrote his own obituary. After he was murdered on Jan. 8, his letter from the grave appeared in papers all over the world including his own, The Sunday Leader in Sri Lanka.'b'His farewell piece is not only a painful explanation of why another brave journalist would die while trying to publish truths that most people are afraid to whisper. It is also a powerful indictment of the increasingly brutal Sri Lankan government, which runs one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a journalist.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo other profession calls on its practitioners to lay down their lives for their art save the armed forces and, in Sri Lanka, journalism,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote in his last editorial, to be published on his death.'b'The Committee to Protect Journalists, which has reported eight journalists killed in Sri Lanka in the last two years, has called for a nonpartisan investigation and diplomatic pressure on Sri Lanka\xe2\x80\x99s president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, to investigate this latest killing. Instead of pursuing those who killed Mr. Wickramatunga, some in the Sri Lankan government have cynically begun suggesting the journalist\xe2\x80\x99s death has benefited the Tamil rebels and others who oppose the Rajapaksa-run state.'b'Mr. Wickramatunga\xe2\x80\x99s final essay catalogs the troubles journalists have suffered in his country \xe2\x80\x94 bombings, killings and coercion \xe2\x80\x94 all while trying to tell about corruption in government and civil rights abuses during an extended civil war. But in a larger sense, his farewell helps explain why some people are willing to give up easier lives to pursue the business of truth-telling.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy then do we do it?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Wickramatunga\xe2\x80\x99s farewell letter asked. \xe2\x80\x9cI often wonder that. After all, I, too, am a husband, and the father of three wonderful children. Is it worth the risk? Many people tell me it is not.\xe2\x80\x9d He then explained why he and so many other journalists take on these jobs around the world, even though more than 700 of their colleagues have been killed since 1992 while trying to film, record or write honestly about what was going on around them.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a calling that is yet above high office, fame, lucre and security,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Wickramatunga wrote before he died for his principles. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the call of conscience.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a recent interview, George Steel, the newly appointed head of the New York City Opera, said of the opera, \xe2\x80\x9cNew York is unthinkable without it.\xe2\x80\x9d And yet it was a very close call.'b'The City Opera has been plagued with woes: a failed search for a new home downtown, the disastrously brief tenure of the company\xe2\x80\x99s last director, Gerard Mortier, and an entire season in the dark while its future home \xe2\x80\x94 the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center \xe2\x80\x94 is being renovated. Whatever else we hope for from Mr. Steel, we hope for stability first.'b'He has his work cut out for him. He will have to struggle to keep the chorus and the orchestra on salary while there are essentially no revenues. And he is facing a fund-raising and endowment crisis, like almost every other institution on the planet.'b'The operatic ground has also shifted in recent years. City Opera used to be a roguish young company compared with the grand dame of Joseph Volpe\xe2\x80\x99s Metropolitan Opera. But Peter Gelb\xe2\x80\x99s Met is staging vibrant, often hip productions that will compete directly for the City Opera audience. We hope that Mr. Steel will hurl himself at these problems with all the passion of an operatic tenor, if perhaps more focus and business sense.'b'His task will be not just to raise money and inspire his company. As he begins to take the measure of the board that hired him, we suspect he may also see the necessity of strengthening that board. New York deserves two opera companies running at the peak of their creative energies. We will be delighted when the day comes when Mr. Steel and his City Opera are ready to challenge Mr. Gelb and the Met to a true operatic duel.'b'Old-fashioned voodoo economics  \xe2\x80\x94 the belief in tax-cut magic  \xe2\x80\x94 has been banished from civilized discourse. The supply-side cult has shrunk to the point that it contains only cranks, charlatans, and Republicans.'b'But recent news reports suggest that many influential people, including Federal Reserve officials, bank regulators, and, possibly, members of the incoming Obama administration, have become devotees of a new kind of voodoo: the belief that by performing elaborate financial rituals we can keep dead banks walking.'b'To explain the issue, let me describe the position of a hypothetical bank that I\xe2\x80\x99ll call Gothamgroup, or Gotham for short.'b'On paper, Gotham has $2 trillion in assets and $1.9 trillion in liabilities, so that it has a net worth of $100 billion. But a substantial fraction of its assets \xe2\x80\x94 say, $400 billion worth \xe2\x80\x94 are mortgage-backed securities and other toxic waste. If the bank tried to sell these assets, it would get no more than $200 billion.'b'So Gotham is a zombie bank: it\xe2\x80\x99s still operating, but the reality is that it has already gone bust. Its stock isn\xe2\x80\x99t totally worthless \xe2\x80\x94 it still has a market capitalization of $20 billion \xe2\x80\x94 but that value is entirely based on the hope that shareholders will be rescued by a government bailout.'b'Why would the government bail Gotham out? Because it plays a central role in the financial system. When Lehman was allowed to fail, financial markets froze, and for a few weeks the world economy teetered on the edge of collapse. Since we don\xe2\x80\x99t want a repeat performance, Gotham has to be kept functioning. But how can that be done?'b'Well, the government could simply give Gotham a couple of hundred billion dollars, enough to make it solvent again. But this would, of course, be a huge gift to Gotham\xe2\x80\x99s current shareholders \xe2\x80\x94 and it would also encourage excessive risk-taking in the future. Still, the possibility of such a gift is what\xe2\x80\x99s now  supporting Gotham\xe2\x80\x99s stock price.'b'A better approach would be to do what the government did with zombie savings and loans at the end of the 1980s: it seized the defunct banks, cleaning out the shareholders. Then it transferred their bad assets to a special institution, the Resolution Trust Corporation; paid off enough of the banks\xe2\x80\x99 debts to make them solvent; and sold the fixed-up banks to new owners.'b'The current buzz suggests, however, that policy makers aren\xe2\x80\x99t willing to take either of these approaches. Instead, they\xe2\x80\x99re reportedly gravitating toward a compromise approach: moving toxic waste from private banks\xe2\x80\x99 balance sheets to a publicly owned \xe2\x80\x9cbad bank\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9caggregator bank\xe2\x80\x9d that would resemble the Resolution Trust Corporation, but without seizing the banks first.'b'Sheila Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, recently tried to describe how this would work: \xe2\x80\x9cThe aggregator bank would buy the assets at fair value.\xe2\x80\x9d But what does \xe2\x80\x9cfair value\xe2\x80\x9d mean?'b'In my example, Gothamgroup is insolvent because the alleged $400 billion of toxic waste on its books is actually worth only $200 billion. The only way a government purchase of that toxic waste can make Gotham solvent again is if the government pays much more than private buyers are willing to offer.'b'Now, maybe private buyers aren\xe2\x80\x99t willing to pay what toxic waste is really worth: \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t have really any rational pricing right now for some of these asset categories,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Bair says. But should the government be in the business of declaring that it knows better than the market what assets are worth? And is it really likely that paying \xe2\x80\x9cfair value,\xe2\x80\x9d whatever that means, would be enough to make Gotham solvent again?'b'What I suspect is that policy makers \xe2\x80\x94 possibly without realizing it \xe2\x80\x94 are gearing up to attempt a bait-and-switch: a policy that looks like the cleanup of the savings and loans,  but in practice amounts to making huge gifts to bank shareholders at taxpayer expense, disguised as \xe2\x80\x9cfair value\xe2\x80\x9d purchases of toxic assets.'b'Why go through these contortions? The answer seems to be that Washington remains deathly afraid of the N-word \xe2\x80\x94 nationalization. The truth is that Gothamgroup and its sister institutions are already wards of the state, utterly dependent on taxpayer support; but nobody wants to recognize that fact and implement the obvious solution: an explicit, though temporary, government takeover. Hence the popularity of the new voodoo, which claims, as I said, that elaborate financial rituals can reanimate dead banks.'b'Unfortunately, the price of this retreat into superstition may be high. I hope I\xe2\x80\x99m wrong, but I suspect that taxpayers are about to get another raw deal \xe2\x80\x94 and that we\xe2\x80\x99re about to get another financial rescue plan that fails to do the job.'b'To the Editor:'b'As discussed in your Jan. 9 editorial \xe2\x80\x9cCuddly Welcome for Mr. Daschle,\xe2\x80\x9d the recent Senate confirmation hearing for our next secretary of health and human services was full of good feelings, but fixing our dysfunctional health care system will take courage and willingness to lead fundamental change.'b'As Mr. Daschle knows, more that two-thirds of each health care dollar is spent on episodes of preventable late-stage chronic disease. Mr. Obama supported such a bankruptcy amendment during his campaign. Committees in both the House and Senate each passed a bankruptcy amendment last year. Now Senate leaders have vowed to pursue a change in the bankruptcy code in their version of the recovery package, which is expected this week. In a push forward for the solution, Citigroup recently endorsed the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s proposed amendment \xe2\x80\x94  recognition, at last, that the financial crisis will not end until defaults and foreclosures abate.'b'The fear is that including the bankruptcy provision in the recovery package will cost votes among Republican senators who oppose the measure, largely out of solidarity with the lending industry. But given the importance of the package, Senate leaders are confident it will safely pass, even with a bankruptcy measure.'b'Mr. Obama can build support for the measure, too, by explaining to the American people that it is a way to begin to solve the foreclosure problem that costs taxpayers nothing. In fact, it would be unconscionable to move forward with taxpayer-financed solutions before putting in place a measure that could help to achieve the desired result without involving taxpayers.'b'The bankruptcy amendment cannot stop all foreclosures. But it is the starting point. And it would be a prime example of government doing for individuals what they cannot do for themselves \xe2\x80\x94 opening a courthouse door that is closed to them by law.'b'Though it seemed to take forever, the Senate last week gave final \xe2\x80\x94 and resounding \xe2\x80\x94 approval to an omnibus public lands bill that would designate more than two million acres across nine states from California to West Virginia as permanent wilderness.'b'The bill now goes to the House of Representatives. We urge the House to accept it quickly and send it to the White House. Most of the bill\xe2\x80\x99s provisions already have been reviewed and approved by one House committee or another. Even a slightly amended bill would have to be returned to the Senate, further delaying an important measure that has been several years in the making.'b'The bill consists of about 160 separate public lands proposals that, among other things, would protect 1,000 miles of wild rivers from commercial development and make modest additions to the national park system. Despite the bill\xe2\x80\x99s reach, pork-barrel projects are, for once, kept to a minimum.'b'The bill\xe2\x80\x99s most controversial proposal \xe2\x80\x94 for a road through a national wildlife refuge in Alaska \xe2\x80\x94 has been revised for the better. It would require a thorough environmental review by the Fish and Wildlife Service, and while the language is a bit vague, it appears to give the interior secretary the right to veto the road.'b'The heart of the bill is the two million acres of new wilderness. The wilderness system now embraces 107 million acres, and this is the biggest addition since 1994. Wilderness areas enjoy a higher level of protection than any other public lands, including national parks, and commercial activities like logging, drilling and residential development are forbidden.'b'A last-minute filibuster threat from Senator Tom Coburn, an Oklahoma Republican, stopped the bill in December. He called it waste of money. Harry Reid, the majority leader, promised to bring it up early this year before the Senate was overwhelmed by new business like the stimulus package. He honored that promise, and the House can now honor the country by passing the bill.'b'Hardly known for vigor or vigilance, the Federal Election Commission is about to undergo well-deserved scrutiny from President-elect Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s administration. The regulator of federal campaigns has a long record of creating loopholes and looking the other way when it comes to policing easy political money.'b'Mr. Obama has assigned a study of the panel\xe2\x80\x99s insular, fitful operations. We hope it\xe2\x80\x99s in preparation for a complete overhaul aimed at truly independent regulation in the public interest \xe2\x80\x94 not more catering to wheel-horse appointees from both parties scheming to circumvent, not uphold, the election laws.'b'The six-member commission has become nigh unto dysfunctional as the three Republican appointees vote together to block any effort to penalize campaign abusers, producing 3-to-3 standoffs on enforcement.'b'The three naysayers rejected a conciliation agreement, worked out by commission staffers, settling obvious violations despite the fact that the accused offender \xe2\x80\x94 a political offshoot of the United States Chamber of Commerce \xe2\x80\x94 accepted the agreement and its penalties. The three also forced a retreat from penalizing a worker who admitted to tapping $65,000 in campaign money for his private accounts. And a candidate who already paid a fine for wholesale filing failures found his check returned after another 3-to-3 deadlock, according to the independent BNA Money and Politics newsletter.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s obvious that the Republican commissioners are out to torpedo the F.E.C. from within and render campaign laws defunct, regardless of an offender\xe2\x80\x99s party.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s decision to reject public financing in the presidential campaign dealt a serious blow to the cause of reform. He will have a chance in the White House to strengthen the system by demanding an appointment process that favors independent nominees, not party hacks.'b'He can start this spring by filling three vacancies at the F.E.C. with vigilant regulators. Traditionally, the president accepts the choices of Congressional leaders. If they suggest their usual round of big-money enablers, Mr. Obama should say thanks but no thanks and name commissioners truly prepared to enforce election law.'b'There are unsettling ghosts of America past all about the National Mall. Hundreds of thousands of people will gather there Tuesday for the inauguration of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s first African-American president. Three blocks from where Barack Obama takes the oath, there was once the Saint Charles Hotel, a popular accommodation on Pennsylvania Avenue before emancipation ruined business for slave traders. It proudly advertised that down below its first-rate restaurant, guests could avail themselves of six, 30-foot-long arched slave cells, replete with wall rings and shackles. The management promised: \xe2\x80\x9cIn case of escape, full value for the Negro will be paid.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A few blocks from there was the notorious Yellow House, a three-story brick slave market where trader William Williams prospered enough to purchase two slave ships of his own. Solomon Northrup, a free man from New York who was kidnapped into slavery, passed through on the block and eventually wrote a memoir. He recalled how \xe2\x80\x9cthe voices of patriotic representatives boasting of freedom and equality,\xe2\x80\x9d in the nearby Capitol almost commingled with \xe2\x80\x9cthe rattling of the poor slave\xe2\x80\x99s chains.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'These and other pre-emancipation tales of the Mall have been painstakingly revived by Jesse Holland, a reporter for The Associated Press. He appreciates the grandeur of Lincoln but also knows the capital\xe2\x80\x99s history is in the gritty details.'b'Mr. Holland found that while the city had a mere 3,100 slaves of its own on the eve of the Civil War, it was an ideal trading platform for slaves bartered Southward by the scores of thousands. The Mall teemed not with tourists, but with pens and blocks \xe2\x80\x9cperfect for the sale of human beings,\xe2\x80\x9d he writes in his book, \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Men Built the Capitol.\xe2\x80\x9d Black men also helped build the White House, as entrepreneurial masters profited from leasing slaves to the government.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe inauguration will be the closing of a circle,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mr. Holland, more knowledgeable than most Americans about some of the cruel and inspiring ways history can work. His research establishes a singular path between today\xe2\x80\x99s inauguration march and a trek from Robey\xe2\x80\x99s Slave Pen and Tavern (where the Department of Education now sits) for sale and shipment South. \xe2\x80\x9cA drove consisting of males and females chained in couples,\xe2\x80\x9d a newspaper noted of slaves routinely herded from Robey\xe2\x80\x99s through the heart of Washington.'b''b'FRANCIS X. CLINES'b''b'And so it has happened, this very strange convergence. The holiday celebrating the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. became, in the midnight hour, the day that America inaugurates its first black president.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a day on which smiles will give way to tears and then return quickly to smiles again, a day of celebration and reflection.'b'Dr. King would have been 80 years old now. He came to national prominence not trying to elect an African-American president, but just trying to get us past the depraved practice of blacks being forced to endure the humiliation of standing up and giving their seat on a bus to a white person, some man or woman or child.'b''b'Get up, girl. Get up, boy.'b''b'Dr. King was just 26 at the time, a national treasure in a stylish, broad-brimmed hat. He was only 39 when he was killed, eight years younger than Mr. Obama is now.'b'There are so many, like Dr. King, who I wish could have stayed around to see this day. Some were famous. Most were not.'b'I remember talking several years ago with James Farmer, one of the big four civil rights leaders of the mid-20th century. (The others were Dr. King, Roy Wilkins and Whitney Young.) Farmer enraged authorities in Plaquemine, La., in 1963 by organizing demonstrations demanding that blacks be allowed to vote. Tired of this affront, a mob of state troopers began hunting Farmer door to door.'b'The southern night trembled once again with the cries of abused blacks. As Farmer described it: \xe2\x80\x9cI was meant to die that night. They were kicking open doors, beating up blacks in the streets, interrogating them with electric cattle prods.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A funeral director saved Farmer by having him \xe2\x80\x9cplay dead\xe2\x80\x9d in the back of a hearse, which carried him along back roads and out of town.'b'Farmer died in 1999. Imagine if he could somehow be seated in a place of honor at the inauguration alongside Dr. King and Mr. Wilkins and Mr. Young. Imagine the stories and the mutual teasing and the laughter, and the deep emotion that would accompany their attempts to rise above their collective disbelief at the astonishing changes they did so much to bring about.'b'And then imagine a tall white man being ushered into their presence, and the warm smiles of recognition from the big four \xe2\x80\x94 and probably tears \xe2\x80\x94 for someone who has been shamefully neglected by his nation and his party, Lyndon Johnson.'b'Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s contributions to the betterment of American life were nothing short of monumental. For blacks, he opened the door to the American mainstream with a herculean effort that resulted in the enactment of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. He followed up that bit of mastery with the Voting Rights Act of 1965.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOnce the black man\xe2\x80\x99s voice could be translated into ballots,\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson would say, \xe2\x80\x9cmany other breakthroughs would follow.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Without Lyndon Johnson, Barack Obama and so many others would have traveled a much more circumscribed path.'b'I wish Johnson could be there, his commitment to civil rights so publicly vindicated, his eyes no doubt misting as the oath of office is administered.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s so easy, now that the moronic face of racism is so seldom openly displayed, to forget how far we\xe2\x80\x99ve really come. When Dr. King delivered his \xe2\x80\x9cI Have a Dream Speech\xe2\x80\x9d at the Lincoln Memorial in 1963, it was illegal, just a stone\xe2\x80\x99s throw away in Virginia, for whites and blacks to marry. Illegal! Just as it is illegal now for gays to marry.'b'Less than a month after the speech, members of the Ku Klux Klan bombed a black church in Birmingham, Ala., where children had gathered for a prayer service. Four girls were killed. Three were 14 years old, and one was 11.'b'My sister, Sandy, and I, growing up in Montclair, N.J., a suburb of New York City, were protected from the harshest rays of racism by a family that would let nothing, least of all some crazy notion of genetic superiority, soil our view of the world or ourselves.'b'My grandparents, who struggled through the Depression and World War II, and my parents, who worked tirelessly to give Sandy and me a wonderful upbringing in the postwar decades, seemed always to have believed that all good things were possible.'b'Even if the doors of opportunity were closed, they didn\xe2\x80\x99t believe they were locked. Hard work, in their eyes, was always the key.'b'Still, the idea of a black president of the United States never came up. Perhaps even for them that was too much to imagine. I wish they could have stayed around long enough to see it.'b'In 1962, Daniel Bell published a book called \xe2\x80\x9cThe End of Ideology.\xe2\x80\x9d The title struck a nerve because it reflected the view, common at the time, that the United States was about to leave behind the brutal, ideological politics that had characterized the 1930s and the early cold war. The 1960s, it was believed, would be a decade of cool pragmatism. Keynesian models would be used to scientifically regulate the economy. Important decisions would be made empirically.'b'Instead, we got what Francis Fukuyama later called The Great Disruption. The information economy began to disrupt the industrial economy. The feminist revolution disrupted gender and family relations. The civil rights revolution disrupted social arrangements. The Vietnam War discredited the establishment.'b'These disruptions were generally necessary and good, but the transition was painful. People lost faith in old social norms, but new ones had not yet emerged. The result was disorder. Divorce rates skyrocketed. Crime rates exploded. Faith in institutions collapsed. Social trust cratered.'b'As community bonds dissolved, individual autonomy asserted itself. Liberals championed the moral liberation of individuals. Conservatives championed their economic liberation. The combined result was a loss of community and social cohesion, and what Christopher Lasch called a culture of narcissism.'b'Instead of ending ideology, the Great Disruption produced ideological politics. The weakening of social norms led to fierce battles as groups vied to create new ones. Personal became political. Groups fought over basic patterns of morality.'b'Republicans tended to win elections because liberals were associated with disorder and conservatives with attempts to restore it. Yet both sides were infected with the same pulverizing style. Politics wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just about allocating resources. It was a contest over values, lifestyles and the status of your tribe. This venomous style dominated politics straight through the two baby boomer presidencies \xe2\x80\x94 of Clinton and Bush.'b'But societies do mend themselves, slowly and organically. In 2002, Rick Warren wrote a phenomenally popular book called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Purpose Driven Life.\xe2\x80\x9d The first sentence was, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not about you.\xe2\x80\x9d That was a sign that the age of expressive individualism was coming to an end. New community patterns and social norms were coalescing.'b'Crime rates had begun to fall, along with teen pregnancy rates and a rash of other social indicators. Young people flocked to perform community service. Couples created families that sought to harvest the gains of feminism while preserving the best of traditionalism.'b'In the cultural realm, the Great Disruption came to an end. New social norms and patterns settled into place. Barack Obama exemplifies the social repair. The product of a scattered family, he has created a highly traditional one, headed by two professionally accomplished adults. To an almost eerie extent, he exemplifies discipline, equipoise and self-control. Under his leadership, as Peter Beinart noted in Time, Democrats came to seem like the party of order while Republicans were associated with disorder.'b'Obama\xe2\x80\x99s challenge will be to translate the social repair that has occurred over the past decade into political and governing repair. Part of that will be done with his inaugural address today. Look for him to emphasize the themes of responsibility, cohesion and unity. Look for him to reject the culture, which lingered in the financial world, of anything goes.'b'Part of that will be done with his governing style. Obama aims to realize the end-of-ideology politics that Daniel Bell and others glimpsed in the early 1960s. He sees himself as a pragmatist, an empiricist. Politics is not personal with him. He does not turn political disagreements into a status contest between one kind of person and another. He is convinced that most Americans practice their politics between the 40-yard lines.'b'Part will be accomplished with his aggressive outreach efforts. Already he has cooperated with Republicans. He has rejected the counsel of the old liberal warriors who want retribution and insularity.'b'But the real test will come in the realm of policy. The next few months will be occupied with the stimulus package. And anybody who is not terrified by the prospect of spending $800 billion hastily has not spent enough time studying the difference between economic textbooks and the way government actually operates.'b'But after that, folks in the Obama camp hope to create a Grand Bargain. That would mean building on a culture of cohesion and tackling the issues that require joint sacrifice \xe2\x80\x94 like reducing deficits, fixing Medicare and Social Security and reforming health care. These problems were insoluble during the era of division and distrust. In the climactic season of his presidency, the winter of 2010, Obama would seek to fundamentally restore balance to American government.'b'If he can do that, the Great Disruption would truly be over. The next chapter in American history would begin on firmer ground.'b'Washington'b'THE past few weeks have been a time to reflect on the legacy of the Bush administration. It has not been a kind time for George W. Bush. Most analyses have been harsh, raking him over the coals for everything from Hurricane Katrina to Abu Ghraib to the financial meltdown to his advocacy of nearly unfettered executive power. I would join in many of those criticisms. But there is one area where President Bush\xe2\x80\x99s legacy will be strong and admirable \xe2\x80\x94 the way he is leaving office.'b'Presidential transitions are always difficult. The United States has an extraordinarily long three-month interregnum during which the person departing the presidency retains full power while the person elected to assume the office waits to take over. I have likened it to a man who moves in with his fianc\xc3\xa9e \xe2\x80\x94 while her soon-to-be former husband still lives in the house. This awkwardness combines with the natural tension between the old and new over policy and personnel that exists even when the outgoing and incoming presidents are in the same party (ask members  of George H. W. Bush and Ronald Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s staffs about the 1988 transition).'b'For an outgoing president, there is always some resentment that the new guy is expected to act as president starting the day after the election; everyone anticipates his policies and ignores the actions of the lame duck. The president is often skittish about providing the newcomer with  top-secret information, in part because the new team is not formally in place. For the president-elect, the outgoing president\xe2\x80\x99s 11th-hour actions, including appointments of his loyalists to career positions, stir resentment.'b'Incoming members of a president-elect\xe2\x80\x99s team often encounter sullenness from their outgoing counterparts, or a false eagerness by some who don\xe2\x80\x99t want to leave their posts at all.'b'Beginning well before the election, President Bush and his chief of staff, Josh Bolten, decided to make this transition different by removing many of the usual obstacles and fostering  cooperation and harmony. President Bush created a formal transition council, headed by Mr. Bolten and including all the people in charge of national security and the economy in his administration, and this group has met regularly to address every action, large and small, that needs to be taken to turn over power.'b'The signals went beyond simple cooperation. Mr. Bolten and Clay Johnson, from the Office of Management and Budget, who had worked on the transition when President Bush came to the White House, expedited the security checks and other administrative processes for Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s nominees. National security briefings were held with the president-elect in Chicago, and a high level of important information was shared with his top aides even before they were assigned to specific posts. It is also clear that Mr. Bush has agreed to make a few difficult or unpopular decisions on his way out so as not to burden Mr. Obama with them \xe2\x80\x94 for example, his request last week that Congress release the second half of the $700 financial billion bailout.'b'To be sure, President Bush has signed some last-minute executive orders, especially in the environmental area, that will create headaches for Mr. Obama. But as a top Obama transition official told me, these were limited in number and scope and all done in the open.'b'A good piece of the credit for the smooth transition is also due to the Obama transition team. But it was important for President Bush to be accommodating, given the nature of this transition, occurring as it does during a time of war and economic crisis. The nation can little afford a rocky transfer of power. America also faces threats from terrorists and other adversaries, and the first few months of a new administration can be a vulnerable time for the nation \xe2\x80\x94 when the full national security and economic teams are not yet in place and no crisis decision-making process has been established.'b'The Bush administration may be leaving the country with big policy problems. But George W. Bush deserves a big gold star for the way he is leaving his office.'b'There was no shortage of powerful imagery on Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Inauguration Day, starting with the confident man who defied all political conventions \xe2\x80\x94 that he was too young, too inexperienced, too black or not black enough \xe2\x80\x94 to stand on the steps of the Capitol and take the oath of office in a city and a country that are still racially divided in many shameful ways.'b'And there was the crowd that for a day, and we hope much longer, defied those divisions. By the hundreds of thousands they came from every part of a nation that has rarely been in such peril and yet is so optimistic about its new leader.'b'In his Inaugural Address, President Obama gave them the clarity and the respect for which all Americans have hungered. In about 20 minutes, he swept away eight years of President George Bush\xe2\x80\x99s false choices and failed policies and promised to recommit to America\xe2\x80\x99s most cherished ideals.'b'With Mr. Bush looking on (and we\xe2\x80\x99d like to think feeling some remorse),  President  Obama declared: \xe2\x80\x9cOn this day, we gather because we have chosen hope over fear, unity of purpose over conflict and discord. On this day, we come to proclaim an end to the petty grievances and false promises, the recriminations and worn- out dogmas that for far too long have strangled our politics.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The speech was not programmatic, nor was it filled with as much soaring language as F.D.R.\xe2\x80\x99s first Inaugural Address or John Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s only one. But it left no doubt how Mr. Obama sees the nation\xe2\x80\x99s problems and how he intends to fix them and, unlike Mr. Bush, the necessary sacrifices he will ask of all Americans.'b'The American story \xe2\x80\x9chas not been the path for  the faint-hearted, for those who prefer leisure over work, or seek only the pleasures of riches and fame,\xe2\x80\x9d he  said.'b'Just as he reshaped the Democratic Party to win its nomination, and the American electorate to defeat John McCain, Mr. Obama said he intended to reshape government so it will truly serve its citizens.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe question we ask today is not whether our  government is too big or too small, but whether it works, whether it helps families find jobs at a decent wage, care they can afford, a retirement that is dignified,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Mr. Obama was unsparing in condemning the failed ideology of uncontrolled markets. He said the current economic crisis showed how \xe2\x80\x9cwithout a watchful eye, the market can spin out of control\xe2\x80\x9d and that the nation has to extend the reach of prosperity to \xe2\x80\x9cevery willing heart, not out of charity, but because it is the surest route to our common good.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Obama also did not shrink from the early criticism of his ambitious economic recovery plan. Rather, he said the \xe2\x80\x9cstate of our economy calls for action, bold and swift,\xe2\x80\x9d to build roads and bridges and electrical power and digital networks, to transform schools, and \xe2\x80\x9charness the sun and the winds and the soil to fuel our cars and run our factories.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'After more than seven years of Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s using fear and xenophobia to justify a disastrous and unnecessary war, and undermine the most fundamental American rights, it was exhilarating to hear Mr. Obama reject \xe2\x80\x9cas false the choice between our safety and our ideals.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Instead of Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s unilateralism, Mr. Obama said the United States is \xe2\x80\x9cready to lead once more,\xe2\x80\x9d by making itself a \xe2\x80\x9cfriend of each nation and every man, woman and child who seeks a future of peace and dignity.\xe2\x80\x9d He said \xe2\x80\x9cour power alone cannot protect us, nor does it entitle us to do as we please.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Obama told the Muslim world that he wants \xe2\x80\x9ca new way forward, based on mutual interest and mutual respect.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Obama was steely toward those \xe2\x80\x9cwho seek to advance their aims by inducing terror and slaughtering innocents.\xe2\x80\x9d He warned them that \xe2\x80\x9cour spirit is stronger and cannot be broken; you cannot outlast us, and we will defeat you.\xe2\x80\x9d But where Mr. Bush painted this as an epochal, almost biblical battle between America and those who hate us and \xe2\x80\x9cwho hate freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Obama also offered to \xe2\x80\x9cextend a hand if you are willing to unclench your fist.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the day continued with a parade and parties and  balls, the image that stayed with us was the way the 44th president managed to embrace the symbolism and rise above it. It filled us with hope that with Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s help, this battered nation will be able to draw together and mend itself.'b'To the Editor:'b'On Tuesday, Barack Obama became the 44th president of the United States.  That he is the first African-American president of a country that only a handful of generations ago fought a bloody civil war that abolished slavery, and only 50 years ago struggled in the streets to bring civil rights to all citizens whatever their color, is a testament to something very good going on in America.'b'The grip of fear, cultural tyranny and bigotry itself has weakened and loosened to a point where, truly, the words of the Rev. And in this struggle the Lord continues to work to bring us opportunities to strive for Him and do the right thing, to grow, to reach for a better life not just without, but a spiritual life within, which honors God, one another and strives to bring good will, respect and honor to all human beings, because they are human beings.'b'Take a moment this week to reflect on this historic inauguration of our 44th president. Perhaps this is a moment in history, within a time of uncertainty, to see a light shine, brighter than before, reflecting in the faces of all people, of all backgrounds and colors, bringing just a little more hope and faith and genuine charity to this world. He summoned the throng before him, and the nation all about, to abandon the \xe2\x80\x9cstale political arguments that have consumed us for so long.\xe2\x80\x9d Show that government does indeed work, was his prescription, yoking the fortunes of both public and president. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off,\xe2\x80\x9d said President Obama, touching the crowd\xe2\x80\x99s craving for something basic, something lately untried.'b'The Obama speech patterns became a separate source of celebration, the way John F. Walking back from the inauguration, I saw an African-American street vendor wearing a home-stenciled T-shirt that pretty well captured the moment \xe2\x80\x94 and then some. It said: \xe2\x80\x9cMission Accomplished.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But we cannot let this be the last mold we break, let alone the last big mission we accomplish. That, for me, was the essence of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inaugural speech and I hope we \xe2\x80\x94 and he \xe2\x80\x94 are really up to it.'b'Indeed, dare I say, I hope Obama really has been palling around all these years with that old Chicago radical Bill Ayers. I hope Obama really is a closet radical.'b'Not radical left or right, just a radical, because this is a radical moment. It is a moment for radical departures from business as usual in so many areas. We can\xe2\x80\x99t thrive as a country any longer by coasting on our reputation, by postponing solutions to every big problem that might involve some pain and by telling ourselves that dramatic new initiatives \xe2\x80\x94 like a gasoline tax, national health care or banking reform \xe2\x80\x94 are too hard or \xe2\x80\x9coff the table.\xe2\x80\x9d So my most fervent hope about President Obama is that he will be as radical as this moment \xe2\x80\x94 that he will put 'b'everything'b' on the table.'b'Opportunities for bold initiatives and truly new beginnings are rare in our system \xe2\x80\x94 in part because of the sheer inertia and stalemate designed into our Constitution, with its deliberate separation of powers, and in part because of the way lobbying money, a 24-hour news cycle and a permanent presidential campaign all conspire to paralyze big changes.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe system is built for stalemate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Michael J. Sandel, the Harvard University political theorist. \xe2\x80\x9cIn ordinary times, the energy and dynamism of American life reside in the economy and society, and people view government with suspicion or indifference. But in times of national crisis, Americans look to government to solve fundamental problems that affect them directly. These are the times when presidents can do big things. These moments are rare. But they offer the occasion for the kind of leadership that can recast the political landscape, and redefine the terms of political argument for a generation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the 1930s, the Great Depression enabled Franklin Roosevelt to launch the New Deal and redefine the role of the federal government, he added, while in the 1960s, the assassination of John F. Kennedy and \xe2\x80\x9cthe moral ferment of the civil rights movement\xe2\x80\x9d enabled Lyndon Johnson to enact his Great Society agenda, including Medicare, the Civil Rights Act and the Voting Rights Act.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThese presidencies did more than enact new laws and programs,\xe2\x80\x9d concluded Sandel. \xe2\x80\x9cThey rewrote the social contract, and redefined what it means to be a citizen. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s moment, and his presidency, could be that consequential.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'George W. Bush completely squandered his post-9/11 moment to summon the country to a dramatic new rebuilding at home. This has left us in some very deep holes. These holes \xe2\x80\x94 and the broad awareness that we are at the bottom of them \xe2\x80\x94 is what makes this a radical moment, calling for radical departures from business as usual, led by Washington.'b'That is why this voter is hoping Obama will swing for the fences. But he also has to remember to run the bases. George Bush swung for some fences, but he often failed at the most basic element of leadership \xe2\x80\x94 competent management and follow-through.'b'President Obama will have to decide just how many fences he can swing for at one time: grand bargains on entitlement and immigration reform? A national health care system? A new clean-energy infrastructure? The nationalization and repair of our banking system? Will it be all or one? Some  now and some later? It is too soon to say.'b'But I do know this: while a crisis is a terrible thing to waste, so too is a great politician, with a natural gift for oratory, a rare knack for bringing people together, and a nation, particularly its youth, ready to be summoned and to serve.'b'So, in sum, while it is impossible to exaggerate what a radical departure it is from our past that we have inaugurated a black man as president, it is equally impossible to exaggerate how much our future depends on a radical departure from our present. MYERSON, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago and a winner of the 2007 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences'b''b'IN an interview last month, 'b'Barack Obama'b' spoke of his and 'b'Michelle'b'\xe2\x80\x99s plans to \xe2\x80\x9copen up the White House and remind people this is the people\xe2\x80\x99s house.\xe2\x80\x9d He said they wanted to host jazz musicians, chamber music recitals and poetry readings, \xe2\x80\x9cso that once again we appreciate this incredible tapestry that\xe2\x80\x99s America.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The allusion to Camelot was unmistakable. Nearly 50 years ago, 'b'Jacqueline Kennedy'b' transformed a shabby White House into an elegant showcase for America\xe2\x80\x99s cultural life and design heritage. Her refurbished state rooms, stocked with historically important furniture arranged with an eye to drama and beauty, became a worthy backdrop for performances, concerts and glamorous dinners. She helped make Americans proud of the place and, for the first time, of our own accomplishments in the decorative arts.'b'This is an appealing model for the Obamas. Unfortunately, they\xe2\x80\x99ll find that Mrs. Kennedy made her own example very hard to follow \xe2\x80\x94 because she pulled it off largely through charm and cunning, and then shrouded her schemes in a welter of bureaucracy that now makes it difficult for any successor to again enliven the d\xc3\xa9cor of the executive mansion.'b'The forlorn state rooms that Mrs. Kennedy found when she and her husband arrived in 1961 \xe2\x80\x94 furnished in Truman-era reproductions of 19th-century pieces from B. Altman and insignificant broadloom carpets \xe2\x80\x94 were desperately in need of revamping. The first lady whipped things into shape in a remarkably short time. She got Congress to pass legislation that designated the White House a museum and hired a curator. She set up the Fine Arts Committee for the White House to locate and raise money for the acquisition of 18th- and 19th-century furniture and art relating to the history of the presidency.'b'Mrs. Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s redesign, which was largely the work of St\xc3\xa9phane Boudin, the celebrated French decorator whose clients included the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, was historically minded rather than historically accurate. In the Green Room, for example, Boudin relied on historical documents to inspire colors, wall coverings and curtains, but his goal was to create a sense of harmony. He arranged the Jeffersonian Federal furniture so as to reconcile the rather leggy, spindly pieces with the room\xe2\x80\x99s enormous proportions.'b'But the first lady cast the work as a \xe2\x80\x9crestoration\xe2\x80\x9d and put Henry Francis du Pont, an  authority on American antiques, at the helm of the committee in order to place all her design decisions beyond reproach. Du Pont and the committee provided cover for Mrs. Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s Parisian decorator. While du Pont gave advice and helped acquire hundreds of important antiques, it was Boudin who had the first lady\xe2\x80\x99s ear. The chief usher of the White House understood he was to allow du Pont to rearrange the furniture during his visits, but then move it back when he left.'b'The American decorator Sister Parish was cannily given credit for some of Boudin\xe2\x80\x99s work on the state rooms, and fabric woven in France was sneaked through customs in a diplomatic pouch. Mrs. Kennedy cleverly sold her remodeling to the American public with a breathy televised tour of the work in progress.'b'The same committee that functioned largely as a charade for Mrs. Kennedy still operates today, to the White House\xe2\x80\x99s detriment. (It\xe2\x80\x99s now known as the Committee for the Preservation of the White House.) Subsequent first ladies have read its preservationist mandate literally, turning many rooms into stultifying period pieces. Pat Nixon and her team replaced, for instance, Boudin\xe2\x80\x99s window treatments in the Green Room with gold-tasseled reproductions  of Federal-era draperies, which robbed the room of its former vitality.  Yesterday, the Obamas stepped into a house whose design influences virtually stop around the end of the 19th century.'b'The Obamas should ignore most of what Jackie Kennedy said and instead do what she actually did \xe2\x80\x94 ideally, without the guile. As she understood, the White House, in order to truly be \xe2\x80\x9cthe people\xe2\x80\x99s house,\xe2\x80\x9d should reflect its living character as much as its history. Mrs. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s appointment of Michael Smith, a Los Angeles-based decorator, is a promising start. He is well versed in the art of Gilbert Stuart and the craftsmanship of Duncan Phyfe, but is unlikely to shy from adding, say, modern paintings by Mark Rothko or furniture by Samuel Marx.'b'Mrs. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s preservation committee, refreshed by the appointment of artists, architects, designers, critics, environmentalists, even philosophers, could pull off a perfect marriage of preservation and progress.'b'The White House ought to reflect the truth that people live surrounded by many historic periods at once \xe2\x80\x94 in our art, music and literature as well as in the d\xc3\xa9cor of the rooms we inhabit. To revive the spirit of Camelot, the Obamas need to show reverence for the past without living in it.'b'WASHINGTON'b'It was the Instant the Earth Stood Still.'b'Not since Klaatu landed in a flying saucer on the Ellipse has Washington been so mesmerized by an object whirring through the sky.'b'But this one was departing, not arriving.'b'As W. ceased to be president, he flew off over the Capitol and across the Mall en route to Andrews Air Force Base, and then back to Texas.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen many presidents come and go, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve never watched a tableau like the one Tuesday, when four million eyes turned heavenward, following the helicopter\xe2\x80\x99s path out of town. Everyone, it seemed, was waving goodbye, with one or two hands, a wave that moved westward down the Mall toward the Lincoln Memorial, and keeping their eyes fixed unwaveringly on that green bird.'b'They wanted to make absolutely, positively certain that W. was gone. It was like a physical burden being lifted, like a sigh went up of \xe2\x80\x9cThank God. Has Cheney\xe2\x80\x99s wheelchair left the building, too?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The crowd was exuberant that George Bush was now an ex-president, and 43 himself was jovial \xe2\x80\x9cthe way he always is,\xe2\x80\x9d according to his last press secretary, Dana Perino.'b'It was like a catharsis in Greek drama, with the antagonist plucked out of the scene into the sky, and the protagonist dropping into the scene to magically fix all the problems.  Except Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s somber mien and restrained oratory conveyed that he\xe2\x80\x99s no divinity and there will be no easy resolution to this plot.'b'It was a morning of such enormous emotion and portent \xe2\x80\x94 jaw-dropping, Dow-dropping and barrier-dropping \xe2\x80\x94 that even the cool new president had to feel daunted to see his blocks-long  motorcade and two million hope-besotted faces beaming up at him, dreaming that he can save their shirts.'b'The optimism was tempered by pessimism, a vibe of \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe this once-in-a-lifetime guy can do it, but boy, there are a lot of never-in-our-lifetime problems here.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Unlike W., Obama is a realist. He knows there is the potential of letting all these blissed-out people down.'b'The day had its jittery moments:  Teddy Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s collapse and   Robert Byrd\xe2\x80\x99s distraught reaction. There was also that  match of the titan smarty-pants  \xe2\x80\x94  the new Democratic president face to face with the conservative chief justice he voted against.'b'First John Roberts had to say, Easy, cowboy, after Mr. Obama jumped the gun on \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d at the start of the oath of office. Then the president, who had obviously been looking over his lines, graciously offered the chief justice a chance to correct his negligent syntax, when he put the \xe2\x80\x9cfaithfully\xe2\x80\x9d and other words out of place.'b'Under the platform, near where I sat, Denzel Washington, Beyonc\xc3\xa9, Jay-Z and P. Is 44 saying I messed everything up?)  \xe2\x80\x94  the newly minted president let him have it:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs for our common defense, we reject as false the choice between our safety and our ideals,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to wild applause (and to Bartlett\xe2\x80\x99s), adding: \xe2\x80\x9cThose ideals still light the world, and we will not give them up for expedience\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\xe2\x80\x9d He said America is choosing hope over fear, unity over discord, setting aside \xe2\x80\x9cfalse promises\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cchildish things.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Letting a little air out of the highest hopes about what one man, even \xe2\x80\x9cThe One,\xe2\x80\x9d can do, he emphasized the word \xe2\x80\x9cour.\xe2\x80\x9d He stressed that rebuilding after the wreckage of W. and Cheney will be a shared burden and that \xe2\x80\x9cgiving our all to a difficult task\xe2\x80\x9d isn\xe2\x80\x99t as bad as it sounds.'b'I grew up here, and it was the first time I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever seen the city wholly, happily integrated, with a mood redolent of New York in the weeks after 9/11. Bush, they would be waterboarded).'b'Two themes were particularly reassuring in Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Inaugural Address. One was his inclusiveness, his effort to tug people into his big tent, a huge contrast from Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s years of governing from an ideological pup tent.'b'President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inclusiveness started with his celebration of America as a patchwork of \xe2\x80\x9cChristians and Muslims, Jews and Hindus \xe2\x80\x94 and nonbelievers.\xe2\x80\x9d If you know of any other sitting president who has dared to embrace atheists (Thomas Jefferson did, but not while in office), post the information on my blog, 'b'nytimes.com/ontheground'b').'b'Mr. Obama was also the first president to use the word \xe2\x80\x9cMuslim\xe2\x80\x9d in an Inaugural Address. In an oblique olive branch that I took to be directed toward Iran and Syria, he said: \xe2\x80\x9cWe will extend a hand if you are willing to unclench your fist.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The second reassuring theme has to do with \xe2\x80\x9chard power\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9csoft power,\xe2\x80\x9d in the terminology of Joseph Nye, a Harvard professor. In the Bush-Cheney years, America sought to rely overwhelmingly on military \xe2\x80\x9chard power,\xe2\x80\x9d and the result was setbacks around the world, from Iran\xe2\x80\x99s accelerated nuclear program to North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s processing of plutonium for a half-dozen nuclear weapons (compared with zero during the Clinton presidency).'b'As my colleague David Sanger documents in his superb new book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Inheritance\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cWe pursued a path that has left us less admired by our allies, less feared by our enemies, and less capable of convincing the rest of the world that our economic and political model is worthy of emulation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s first attempt at soft power is the nifty new White House Web site, complete with a White House blog. In his Inaugural Address, Mr. Obama focused on soft power alongside hard power: \xe2\x80\x9cOur security emanates from the justness of our cause, the force of our example, the tempering qualities of humility and restraint.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Tempering qualities? Dick Cheney never wanted to temper anything, including his temper.'b'This mix of soft and hard power is what Professor Nye calls \xe2\x80\x9csmart power\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 an update of Teddy Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s notion of speaking softly and carrying a big stick \xe2\x80\x94 and it seems to be an emerging theme of the new administration. Hillary Rodham Clinton emphasized it in her confirmation hearings.'b'Professor Nye said that Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inaugural was a perfect example of smart power. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not going to make our adversaries roll over, but it\xe2\x80\x99ll help in terms of mainstream Muslims and it\xe2\x80\x99ll help in terms of allies,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Nye said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it\xe2\x80\x99ll give a very different tone to foreign policy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Now the world will be watching to see if Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s policy matches his rhetoric. The economy will be paramount, of course, but it will take months or years to judge results there.'b'In the meantime, there are two immediate litmus tests by which the world will begin to judge Mr. Obama at once. The first will be his handling of Guant\xc3\xa1namo and torture  \xe2\x80\x94  the architects of those Bush policies did more damage to America than anyone confined in Guant\xc3\xa1namo  \xe2\x80\x94  and it was reassuring that Mr. Obama promptly suspended action by military tribunals.'b'A second test is Middle East policy. The Bush policy of (mostly) disengagement and obliviousness to Palestinian suffering has made it harder to achieve a peace that is the best hope for Israelis and Palestinians alike. Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s calls Wednesday to Middle Eastern leaders were helpful, and he should immediately make clear that he wants Israel to halt the settlements and ease repressive restrictions on the West Bank.'b'These steps would reassure the world that its hopes for a new day in Washington just may be justified.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 President Obama made a responsible speech for \xe2\x80\x9ca new era of responsibility\xe2\x80\x9d that is set to include a \xe2\x80\x9cresponsible\xe2\x80\x9d withdrawal from Iraq. Standing at the west front of the Capitol, he was not at his most uplifting, nor his most inspiring, as he called in sober tones for a new \xe2\x80\x9cspirit of service\xe2\x80\x9d that will renew America and, through it, the world.'b'I sat 30 feet away and felt stirred but not transported. Perhaps that was the point. There\xe2\x80\x99s too much work to do for high rhetorical flourish.'b'The day was bright but freezing. The trombones of the Marine Band glinted in the unforgiving light. The sun proceeded in its slow arc to noon, yet it seemed to grow colder, as if nature itself were stilled.'b'A shivering crowd of more than one million stretched back across the National Mall toward the Lincoln Memorial. But the Great Liberator, freer of slaves in a terrible war, was passed over in silence. So, too, was the throng.'b'The symbols, like the national catharsis, could speak for themselves, just as the 21-gun salute to an African-American president contained its own eloquence. According to this superstition, Captain Kirk made a grammatical error when he declared that the five-year mission of the starship Enterprise was \xe2\x80\x9cto boldly go where no man has gone before\xe2\x80\x9d; it should have been \xe2\x80\x9cto go boldly.\xe2\x80\x9d Likewise, Dolly Parton should not have declared that \xe2\x80\x9cI will always love you\xe2\x80\x9d but \xe2\x80\x9cI always will love you\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cI will love you always.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Any speaker who has not been brainwashed by the split-verb myth can sense that these corrections go against the rhythm and logic of English phrasing. The myth originated centuries ago in a thick-witted analogy to Latin, in which it is impossible to split an infinitive because it consists of a single word, like dicere, \xe2\x80\x9cto say.\xe2\x80\x9d But in English, infinitives like \xe2\x80\x9cto go\xe2\x80\x9d and future-tense forms like \xe2\x80\x9cwill go\xe2\x80\x9d are two words, not one, and there is not the slightest reason to interdict adverbs from the position between them.'b'Though the ungrammaticality of split verbs is an urban legend, it found its way into The Texas Law Review Manual on Style, which is the arbiter of usage for  many law review journals.
